fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: OBJECTIVE: To compare the available evidence on intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens for the prevention of postpartum hemorrhage following cesarean delivery.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: DATA SOURCES: We searched Ovid MEDLINE Embase Global Index Medicus Cumulative Index of Nursing and Allied Health Literature Cochrane Controlled Register of Trials ClinicalTrials.gov and the International Clinical Trials Registry Platform for eligible studies pub- lished until February 2020.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: STUDY ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA: We included any randomized or nonrandomized study published in peer-reviewed journals that compared at least 2 different dosing regimens of intravenous oxytocin for postpartum hemorrhage prevention in women undergoing cesarean delivery.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: METHODS: Two authors independently assessed the eligibility of studies extracted the data and assessed the risk of bias.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: The primary outcome was incidence of postpartum hemorrhage 1000 mL.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Other review outcomes included use of additional uterotonics blood loss and adverse maternal events.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Data were analyzed according to the type of intravenous administration (bolus only infusion only or bolus plus infusion) and total oxytocin dose.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: A meta-analysis was performed on randomized trials and the results were reported as risk ratios or mean differences with 95% conﬁdence intervals.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: The Grading of Recommendations Assessment Development and Evaluations scale was used to rate the certainty of evidence.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Findings from dose-ﬁnding trials and nonrandomized studies were reported narratively.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: RESULTS: A total of 35 studies (7333 women) met our inclusion criteria and included 30 randomized trials and 5 nonrandomized studies.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: There were limited data available from the trials for most outcomes and the results were not conclusive.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Compared with bolus plus infusion regimens bolus only regimens probably result in slightly higher mean blood loss (mean difference 52 mL 95% conﬁdence interval 0.4e104 mL moderate certainty).

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Among the bolus plus infusion regimens initial bolus doses <5 IU may reduce nausea (risk ratio 0.26 95% conﬁdence interval 0.11e0.63 low certainty) when compared with doses of 5e9 IU.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Total oxytocin doses of 5e9 IU vs total doses of 10e19 IU may increase the use of additional uterotonics (risk ratio 13.00 95% conﬁdence interval 1.75e96.37 low certainty).

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Effects on other outcomes were generally inconclusive.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: CONCLUSION: There are limited data available for comparisons of IV oxytocin regimens for postpartum hemorrhage prevention following cesarean delivery.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Bolus plus infusion regimens may lead to minor reductions in mean blood loss and initial bolus doses of <5 IU may minimize nausea.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Bolus only regimens of 10 IU vs bolus only regimens of 5 IU may decrease the need for additional uterotonics however further comparative trials are required to understand the effects on other key outcomes particularly hypotension.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Key words: abdominal delivery birth blood loss dosing drug administration pregnancy uterine atony uterotonics 250 American Journal of Obstetrics & Gynecology SEPTEMBER 2021 Systematic Reviews ajog.org global efforts to reduce PPH-associated morbidity and mortality.4 In 2018 the World Health Organiza- tion (WHO) recommended that 10 in- ternational units (IU) of oxytocin should be administered to all women during delivery irrespective of the mode of de- livery (vaginal or cesarean delivery [CD]).4 This recommendation was informed by a Cochrane network meta- analysis of uterotonic agents for PPH prevention by Gallos et al.5 Based on further evidence from observational studies suggesting dose-dependent adverse effects 4 the WHO recommen- dations speciﬁed that when used for PPH prevention during CD 10 IU oxytocin should be administered as a divided dose using a smaller initial intravenous (IV) bolus followed by infusion.4 However the WHO Guideline Development Group acknowledged that there was insufﬁcient evidence from randomized controlled trials and speciﬁed that identifying an optimal IV oxygocin regimen for PPH prophylaxis during CD was a high research priority.4 Previous reports have synthesized ev- idence on oxytocin dosing regimens for PPH prevention during CD however none of these were systematic reviews or were published nearly a decade ago.6e8 An up-to-date review and comparison of studies are important to help guide clinical practice and address the priority identiﬁed by the WHO Guideline Development Group.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: The aim of this systematic review was therefore to identify and compare IVoxytocin dosing regimens during CD and determine whether any regimens are superior.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Methods We conducted a systematic review in accordance with the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta- Analyses (PRISMA) guidance9 (Appendix A).

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: We followed a prespeciﬁed protocol registered with the International Prospec- tive Register of Systematic Reviews (CRD42020175544) 10 and outlined any deviations in Appendix B.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Ethics approval was not required because this was a systematic review of publicly available data.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Eligibility criteria Randomized controlled trials (RCTs) and nonrandomized studies of interventions (NRSIs) published in peer-reviewed journals were eligible for inclusion without date restrictions.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Conference abstracts were not included.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: We included studies written in English and those written in other languages if we were able to obtain adequate translations.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Eligible studies were those that included women who gave birth at any gestational age to a live or stillborn baby via CD and included both planned and intrapartum CDs.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Women were eligible if they received IV oxytocin for PPH prevention either at or around the third stage of labor recognizing that admin- istration of oxytocin during the third stage may not be possible or practical during a CD particularly during an emergency CD.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Studies comparing at least 2 different IV dosing regimens of oxytocin during CD were eligible.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Trials with coad- ministered interventions were eligible provided that the use of cointerventions was identical in all trial arms.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Outcomes of interest We prespeciﬁed 25 outcomes based on those used in the WHO recommenda- tions on uterotonics for PPH preven- tion 4 the PPH core outcome set 11 and the 2019 Cochrane network meta- analysis on uterotonics for PPH pre- vention.5 The primary review outcome was incidence of PPH 1000 mL with secondary outcomes including PPH 500 mL maternal death severe maternal morbidity (intensive care unit [ICU] admissions) severe maternal morbidity (shock) use of additional uterotonics satisfactory uterine tone use of surgical or invasive nonsurgical interventions blood transfusion mean volumes of blood loss change in he- moglobin measurements before vs after birth any adverse maternal events (including nausea vomiting headache hypotension chest pain myocardial ischemia cardiac arrythmia dyspnea bradycardia tachycardia or water intoxication) breastfeeding at hospital discharge maternal sense of well-being and maternal satisfaction.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Information sources search strategy and study selection A search strategy was developed in consultation with an information specialist (Supplemental Table 1).

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Be- tween February 14 2020 and February 19 2020 we searched the following 7 electronic databases: Ovid MEDLINE Embase Global Index MedicusAJOG at a Glance Why was this study conducted?

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: The World Health Organization guidelines state that there is insufﬁcient evidence to recommend a speciﬁc oxytocin dosing regimen to prevent women from experiencing postpartum hemorrhage following a cesarean delivery.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: This sys- tematic review was conducted to identify and compare intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens administered during cesarean deliveries and to determine whether any regimens are superior.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Key ﬁndings We found limited and generally low-quality data for most outcomes and further research is required.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Bolus plus infusion regimens with an initial bolus dose of <5 international units (IU) may have minor beneﬁts.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Bolus only regimens of 10 IU vs 5 IU may decrease the use of additional uterotonics although the effects on adverse events (particularly hypotension) is unknown.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: What does this add to what is known?

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: This study compared data on all oxytocin regimens administered during cesarean delivery for postpartum hemorrhage prevention.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: It provides valuable information for clinical guidelines and future research.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: ajog.org Systematic Reviews SEPTEMBER 2021 American Journal of Obstetrics & Gynecology 251 Cumulative Index of Nursing and Allied Health Literature Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials ClinicalTrials.gov and WHO Interna- tional Clinical Trials Registry Platform.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Recovered citations were de-duplicated using Endnote (Clarivate Analytics Philadelphia PA)12 and imported into Covidence (Covidence Melbourne Australia)13 for screening.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Each unique citation was reviewed and independently assessed by 2 review authors (L.C.P.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: E.K.F.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: and M.C.) for inclusion initially based on titles and abstracts and then on the full-text articles of potentially eligible citations.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Disagreements were resolved through discussion or consultation with another reviewer (J.P.V.).

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: We also screened the reference lists of all included studies in addition to the reference list of the Gallos et al5 network meta-analysis for additional eligible studies.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Data extraction and assessment of risk of bias For each study 2 reviewers (L.C.P.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: E.K.F.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: M.C.) double-extracted data us- ing a predesigned and pretested elec- tronic spreadsheet (Google Sheets).

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Data about the study design year of publica- tion period of recruitment number of participants maternal age gestational age primary and secondary review out- comes and potential effect modiﬁers (type of CD previous oxytocin admin- istration during childbirth and previous risk for PPH) were extracted.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Disagree- ments between the reviewers at the title and abstract and full-text stages were 4% and 9% respectively and were resolved through discussion or consul- tation with another reviewer (J.P.V.).

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: We attempted to contact the study authors for all studies for which further infor- mation was required.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Each included study was assessed for risk of bias by at least 2 review authors (L.C.P.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: E.K.F.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: RCTs were assessed using the Cochrane Risk Of Bias 2.0 (ROB 2.0 Cochrane London United Kingdom) tool 14 and NRSIs were assessed using the Risk Of Bias In Non- randomized Studies of Interventions (ROBINS-I Cochrane) tool.15 We made an explicit judgment about the overallrisk of bias for each included study.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: In addition we assessed the risk of bias of blood loss measurements using a similar approach to Gallos et al5 (Supplemental Table 2).

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Extracted data about the re- view outcomes from RCTs were entered into the Review Manager 5 software (Cochrane)16 for the meta-analysis.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Data from NRSIs were reported narratively.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Data synthesis We identiﬁed the following 3 types of studies: comparative RCTs with 2 arms dose-ﬁnding RCTs and NRSIs.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Comparative randomized controlled trials.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: For comparative RCTs we ﬁrst assessed trial populations and methods used between trials to judge whether they were sufﬁciently similar to warrant a meta-analysis.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: A random-effects model was used to assess all outcomes with >1 trial.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Results from dichotomous data were presented as a summary risk ratio (RR) with 95% conﬁdence intervals (CI) and as mean differences (MDs) for continuous data.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: For all meta-analyses we used the Grading of Recommenda- tions Assessment Development and Evaluation (GRADE) approach17 to rate the certainty of evidence as very low low moderate or high using GRADEpro software (Evidence Prime Inc Ontario Canada).18 We planned to assess publi- cation bias using funnel plots if there were 10 or more studies included in the meta- analysis however this was not done because of the limited number of studies.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: We conducted separate meta-analyses for (1) type of IV administration (bolus only infusion only or bolus plus infu- sion) and (2) total oxytocin dose administered.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: We calculated the total oxytocin dose for each trial arm by adding all preplanned doses of oxytocin described in the study methods including any doses used in a bolus short infusion and maintenance infu- sion (studies were not included for analysis of total oxytocin dose if there was insufﬁcient information to deter- mine the total dose).

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Considering the available evidence (and to standardize the analyses) trial arms were grouped into 5 total oxytocin dose categories (<5 IU 5e9 IU 10e19 IU 20e49 IU and50 IU) for comparison in pairwise analyses.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: In addition among trials using bolus plus infusion regimens we iden- tiﬁed trials that studied the effects of using different initial bolus doses by varying the initial bolus dose while keeping the infusion component iden- tical between trial arms.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Hence we also analyzed (3) the effects of different initial bolus doses among trials using bolus plus infusion regimens.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: To accomplish this we grouped the initial bolus doses as <5 IU 5 IU or 10 IU for comparison in pairwise analyses.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: In line with the 2019 international consensus statement recommendation of a 2- to 4-hour maintenance infusion 8 we performed a subgroup analysis on studies that used a maintenance infusion be- tween 2 and 4 hours only.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Owing to limited available data we were only able to perform this for the analysis of initial bolus doses in a bolus plus infusion regimen.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: We planned to conduct subgroup analyses by type of CD (planned vs intrapartum) previous oxytocin admin- istration and previous risk of PPH however these were not possible because of limited available data.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: We performed sensitivity analyses for risk of bias (only including studies with an overall low risk of bias) and method of blood loss esti- mation (only including studies that used calculated or volumetric assessment of blood loss).

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: When making statements on the effects of an intervention we adopted standardized language derived from San- tesso et al.19Dose-ﬁnding trials and nonrandomized studies.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: The dose-ﬁnding RCTs used a 1-arm up- and-down sequential allocation method in which the oxytocin dose for the next participant was adjusted according to the response of the preceding participant.20For example if the ﬁrst participant had a satisfactory response the next partici- pant was allocated either an equal or lower dose using a biased-coin technique.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Dose-ﬁnding trials did not make explicit pairwise comparisons between dosing regimens hence ﬁndings from these trials were reported narratively.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Eligible NRSIs were also reported narratively.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Systematic Reviews ajog.org 252 American Journal of Obstetrics & Gynecology SEPTEMBER 2021 Results Study selection and characteristics The results of the search are summarized in the PRISMA ﬂow diagram (Figure 1).

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: We identiﬁed 9631 records of which 6626 records were excluded at the title and abstract screening stage and 195 at the full-text review stage.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: The most common reasons for exclusion were duplicate study (n¼72) and wrong article type (n¼37).

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: No further articles were identiﬁed through screening of the reference lists.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: In total 35 studies of 7333 women were included.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: We found 30 RCTs of which 26 were comparative RCTs and 4 were dose-ﬁnding RCTs.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: We found 5 NRSIs of which 4 were comparative and 1 was a dose-ﬁnding study.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: A summary of the study charac- teristics and an overview of study com- parisons are provided in Tables 1 to 4 and Supplemental Table 3.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Among the 26 comparative RCTs included 9 were at an overall high risk for bias and 15 were at low risk for bias (Supplemental Figures 1 and 2) the 4 dose-ﬁnding RCTs were assessed to be at an overall high risk for bias.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Of the 5 NRSIs 2 were assessed to be at an overall critical risk of bias and the remaining 3 as at moderate risk (Supplemental Figures 3 and 4).

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Comparative randomized controlled trials We identiﬁed 26 comparative RCTs (64 trial arms) that included 5271 women.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Of these 19 RCTs were 2-arm trials and 7 RCTs were multi-arm trials (ranging from 3e6 arms).

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Sample sizes ranged from 28e2069 women and 23 trials included women undergoing planned CD only.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: The types of IVadministrations used were bolus only (14 arms) infusion only (23 arms) and bolus plus infusion (27 arms).

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: There were 26 different total doses of oxytocin used ranging from 1 IUe260 IU.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: The most common total doses were 5 IU (11 arms) and 10 IU (8 arms).

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: We could not calculate the total dose for 3 of the studies.25 27 35 Among those trial arms that used an infusion component the total infusion duration ranged from 5 minutes to 24 hours and the rate of oxytocin administration var- ied from 0.7 IU per hour to 120 IU per hour.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Among the 5 trials that compareddifferent initial bolus doses within a bolus plus infusion regimen the initial bolus doses ranged from 0.5e10 IU.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Dose-ﬁnding trials and nonrandomized studies We identiﬁed 4 dose-ﬁnding RCTs (180 women).

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: The sample sizes ranged from 30e70 women.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Two trials included women undergoing planned CD only and 1 trial included women undergoing intrapartum CD only.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: All studies used either an initial bolus or infusion fol- lowed by a maintenance infusion.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: We found 5 NRSIs that included 1840 women with sample sizes ranging from 41e1122 women.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Of these 4 werecomparative studies (3 2-arm studies 1 3-arm study) and 1 was a dose-ﬁnding study.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: The most common type of IV administration was bolus only (4 arms).

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Doses ranged from 3e80 IU with the most common dose being 5 IU (2 arms).

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Outcomes The most commonly reported outcomes were the use of additional uterotonics (28 studies) and mean blood loss (20 studies).

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: No data were available for 7 outcomes (maternal deaths ICU ad- missions shock water intoxication breastfeeding after discharge maternal sense of well-being and maternal sense of satisfaction (Supplemental Table 4).

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: A total of 15 RCTs (3921 women) compared different types of IV admin- istration regimens (Table 2Supplemental Table 5).

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: The incidence of PPH 1000 mL was only reported for 1 comparison (bolus only vs bolus plus infusion).

text: Bolus only vs infusion only.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: In 5 RCTs (338 women) bolus only regimens were compared with infusion only regimens.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: No study reported on the outcome of incidence of PPH 1000 mL.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: The effects of either dosing regimen on the use of additional uterotonics mean blood loss or maternal adverse effects (nausea vomiting chest pain and myocardial ischemia) are inconclusive because the certainty of evidence was very low.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: No other outcomes were reported.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Bolus only vs bolus plus infusion.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: In 5 RCTs (4580 women) bolus only regi- mens were compared with bolus plus infusion regimens.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: The effect of either dosing regimen on the outcome of incidence of PPH 1000 mL was inconclusive because the certainty of evidence was very low (4 trials of 2976 women RR 1.44 95% CI 0.75e2.76 very low certainty) although bolus only regimens slightly increased the mean blood loss (5 trials of 3068 women MD 52 mL 95% CI 0.4e104 mL moderate certainty) (Figure 2) and decreased the incidence of satisfactory uterine tone (1 trial of 145 women RR 0.63 95% CI 0.41e0.95 low certainty) (Figure 3).

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: There were no clear differences in themean change in hemoglobin (3 trials of 2260 women MD e0.05 g/dL 95% CI e0.27 to 0.17 g/dL high certainty) or incidence of blood transfusion (3 trials of 2870 women RR 1.55 95% CI 0.47e5.13 low certainty).

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: The effects of either dosing regimen on the outcomes of incidence of PPH 500 mL use of additional uterotonics and maternal adverse effects (hypotension nausea and chest pain) were inconclusive because the certainty of evidence was very low.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: There were zero events re- ported for surgical or nonsurgical in- terventions vomiting bradycardia tachycardia and dyspnea.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: A sensitivity analysis on risk of bias (including only studies at an overall low risk of bias) suggested no clear difference in mean blood loss.

text: In 5 RCTs (442 women) infusion only regimens were compared with bolus plus infusion regimens.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: No study re- ported on the outcome of incidence of PPH 1000 mL.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: There were no clear differences in the incidence of satisfac- tory uterine tone (2 trials of 164 women RR 0.98 95% CI 0.90e1.06 low certainty) blood transfusion (1 trial of 145 women RR 0.35 95% CI 0.04e3.26 low certainty) or maternal adverse events (vomiting [1 trial of 60 women RR 0.50 95% CI 0.06e4.18 low certainty] headache [1 trial of 152 women RR 0.36 95% CI 0.01e8.71 low certainty] hypotension [2 trials of 263 women RR 0.60 95% CI 0.34e1.05 moderate certainty] cardiac arrythmia [1 trial of 60 women RR1.50 95% CI 0.27e8.34 low cer- tainty] and tachycardia [1 trial of 143 women RR 0.96 95% CI 0.06e15.04 low certainty]).

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: The effects on use of additional uterotonics mean blood loss and nausea were inconclusive because the certainty of evidence was very low.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens

text: The use of a total dose of 10e19 IU compared with of 20e49 IUprobably reduces chest pain (1 trial of 271 women RR 0.05 95% CI 0.00e0.81 moderate certainty) (Supplemental Figure 5).

text: There were no clear differences in the incidence of blood transfusion (1 trial of 271 women RR 0.86 95% CI 0.28e2.62 low cer- tainty) satisfactory uterine tone (1 trial of 271 women RR 1.05 95% CI 1.00e1.09 moderate certainty) or tachycardia (1 trial of 271 women RR 0.84 95% CI 0.26e2.69).

text: It did not report on the inci- dence of PPH 1000 mL.

text: The use of doses of 20e49 IU compared with 50 IU may increase the use of additional uterotonics (RR 2.07 95% CI 1.42e3.01 low certainty) (Supplemental Figure 6).

text: Different bolus doses in bolus plus infusion regimens.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: A total of 5 RCTs using oxytocin regimens of bolus plus infusion (357 women) compared different initial bolus doses while keeping the infusion component identical for both trial arms (Table 4 Supplemental Table 7).

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Initial bolus dose of <5 IU vs 5 IU in a bolus plus infusion regimen.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: In 3 RCTs (180 women) in which a bolus plus infusion regimen was used an initial bolus dose of <5 IU was compared with that of 5 IU.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: No study reported on the incidence of PPH 1000 mL.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Data from all 3 trials showed that initial bolus doses of <5 IU may reduce nausea (RR 0.29 95% CI 0.10e0.81 low certainty) (Supplemental Figure 7) but there were no clear differences in the use of addi- tional uterotonics (RR 1.08 95% CI 0.51e2.31 low certainty) or vomiting (RR 0.23 95% CI 0.05e1.04 low cer- tainty).

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: The effect on mean blood loss was very uncertain owing to very low certainty about the evidence.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: There were zero events reported for surgical or nonsurgical interventions blood trans- fusions and maternal adverse events (chest pain cardiac arrythmia dyspnea hypotension).

text: ajog.org Systematic Reviews SEPTEMBER 2021 American Journal of Obstetrics & Gynecology 259 Initial bolus dose of 5 IU vs 10 IU in a bolus plus infusion regimen.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: One RCT24(87 women) that employed a bolus plus infusion regimen compared an initial bolus dose of 5 IU with 10 IU.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: It did not report on the incidence of PPH 1000 mL and there were no clear differences in mean blood loss (MD 2 mL 95% CI e135 to 138 mL low certainty) cardiac arrythmia (RR 0.34 95% CI 0.01e8.14 low certainty) or chest pain (RR 0.41 95% CI 0.08e2.00 low certainty).

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: There were zero events reported for surgical or nonsurgical interventions and dyspnea.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: We were largely unable to perform sensitivity and subgroup analyses owing to limited available data.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: However where data permitted these analyses no sig- niﬁcant effects were found except where otherwise described.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Narrative synthesis.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: We reviewed dose-ﬁnding RCTs and NRSIs separately.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Findings from these studies are inconclusive however we report the main ﬁndings below.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: The re- sults were not reported as statistically signiﬁcant unless otherwise noted.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Dose-ﬁnding studies.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: A total of 4 dose- ﬁnding RCTs (180 women) studied the different initial doses required to initiate uterine contraction when followed by a maintenance infusion.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: No study re- ported on the incidence of PPH 1000 mL.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: The studies found that small doses (0.3 IU as a bolus or 0.27e0.29 IU/min as a short infusion) may be adequate to prevent uterine atony during plannedCD48e50 and that higher doses of oxytocin may be required during intra- partum CD regardless of the type of administration.47 50 One dose-ﬁnding NRSI55 (83 women) reported that small doses (1 IU as a bolus) may be adequate to prevent uterine atony with higher doses needed during intrapartum CD.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Hypotension secondary to oxytocin administration was noted in all studies however was not explored in relation to speciﬁc doses or types of IV adminis- tration regimens.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Nonrandomized studies.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Type of intravenous administration.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: One study52 (1122 women critical risk of bias) compared bolus only with bolus plus infusion regimens.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: It suggested that more women who received bolus only regi- mens experienced PPH 1000 mL than women who received bolus plus infusion regimens greater use of additional ute- rotonics and increased incidence in blood transfusions.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: There were no sig- niﬁcant differences reported for any other outcomes.52 Another study53 (454 women moderate risk of bias) compared infusion only with bolus plus infusion regimens.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: It did not report on the inci- dence of PPH 1000 mL but suggested that women who received infusion only regimens experienced a greater overall decrease in hemoglobin levels.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Total oxytocin dose.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: One study54 (73 women moderate risk of bias) compared a total oxytocin dose of 3 IU with that of 5 IU.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: It did not report on the incidence of PPH 1000 mL butsuggested more women who received 5 IU experienced vomiting when compared with women who received 3 IU.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: One study52 (1122 women critical risk of bias) compared a total oxytocin dose of 5 IU with that of 10 IU and 15 IU.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: It suggested that increased doses of oxytocin may result in less PPH 1000 mL the use of additional uterotonics and blood transfusions and may lead to more satisfactory uterine tone.52 One study51 (150 women critical risk of bias) compared a total oxytocin dose of 30 IU with that of 80 IU.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: It did not report on the incidence of PPH 1000 mL but suggested that 30 IU may lead to a sta- tistically signiﬁcant increase in the use of additional uterotonics and a decrease in satisfactory uterine tone.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: No signiﬁcant differences were reported for any other outcomes including hypotension.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Comment Main ﬁndings We identiﬁed 35 studies of 7333 women comparing different IV oxytocin regi- mens for PPH prevention following CD.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: The evidence in general was limited and data were lacking for most of the review outcomes with the data from 11 studies at high or critical risk of bias.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: We did not ﬁnd any clear differences in the incidence of PPH 1000 mL although data were sparse for this outcome.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Bolus plus infusion regimens are possibly superior to bolus only regimens in terms of a small reduction in mean blood loss (around 52 mL) and increased uterineFIGURE 4 Total oxytocin dose of 5e9 IU vs 10e19 IU: use of additional uterotonics CI conﬁdence interval.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Phung.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Oxytocin dosing regimens for postpartum hemorrhage prevention following cesarean delivery.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Am J Obstet Gynecol 2021.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Systematic Reviews ajog.org 260 American Journal of Obstetrics & Gynecology SEPTEMBER 2021 tone although these ﬁndings were based on a few trials.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: In general we found no clear indication of a superior total oxytocin dose (largely because of insuf- ﬁcient evidence).

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Although we found doses of 10e19 IU is possibly better than doses of 5e9 IU in terms of decreasing the use of additional uterotonics there were limited data on adverse maternal events (particularly hypotension).

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Of interest both studies used in the meta- analysis of this outcome exclusively compared 5 IU with 10 IU in a bolus only regimen.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Oxytocin regimens were described using varying time intervals which complicated meaningful comparison.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: However available evidence suggests that when administering oxytocin in a bolus plus infusion regimen initial bolus doses of <5 IU may lead to less nausea but the effects of lower vs higher initial bolus doses on blood loss are not known.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: The infusion component of bolus plus infusion regimens most commonly continued for 2e4 hours.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Findings from nonrandomized studies although not conclusive owing to a greater susceptibility to bias were broadly consistent with the ﬁndings of meta-analyses on RCTs.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: These generally indicated that bolus plus infusion regi- mens may be superior to bolus only regimens and that higher oxytocin doses may be more effective but can increase adverse maternal events.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Among the bolus plus infusion regimens 4 dose- ﬁnding RCTs reported that small initial doses (0.3 IU as a bolus or 0.27e0.29 IU/ min as a short infusion) may be adequate to prevent uterine atony during planned CD 48e50 with higher doses required at intrapartum CD 47 50 but the evidence was not conclusive and should be inter- preted with caution.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Comparison with existing literature Our ﬁndings are broadly consistent with previous work on IV oxytocin dosing regimens for PPH prevention following at CD including a 2012 systematic re- view7 of 7 RCTs (626 women) and a 2011 literature review.6 Both reviews recom- mended the use of a small initial bolus dose (ranging between 0.3 and 3 IU)6 7 with 1 review further recommending a bolus plus infusion regimen.7 Both re- views further reported more adverse hemodynamic events with higher doses of oxytocin which is consistent with our ﬁndings.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Our ﬁndings are compatible with a 2019 international consensus statement 8 which recommends using a 1 IU bolus followed by a 2.5e7.5 IU/h infusion over 2e4 hours and the WHO recommendation of 10 IU oxytocin administered IVor intramuscular during all births with doses divided into a small initial IV bolus with subsequent infusion during CD.4 However it is evident that good-quality trials comparing different oxytocin dosing regimens are needed to guide practice.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: It is noteworthy to mention that national guidelines vary (Supplemental Table 8) probably reﬂecting the lack of clear evidence to guide practice.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: The 2017 American College of Obstetricians and Gynecolo- gists guidelines recommend using a dilute IV infusion (bolus dose of 10 IU) for PPH prevention without speciﬁca- tion for mode of delivery.57 Australian guidelines only recommend prophylac- tic oxytocin for all births without speci- fying a dosing regimen.61 Carbetocin is recommended in Canada during plan- ned CD 60 and a bolus only oxytocin regimen is recommended in the United Kingdom.58 French guidelines recom- mend a oxytocin bolus plus infusion regimen during CD however suggest an initial bolus dose of 5e10 IU.59Strengths and limitations We used a systematic and methodologi- cally robust approach to searching and analyzing literature without date or language restrictions.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: We included both randomized and nonrandomized studies which allowed for a more thor- ough and nuanced investigation of oxytocin dosing regimens.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: We also pre- speciﬁed outcomes that aligned with WHO priority outcomes4 and the PPH core outcome set11 and used the latest and more sophisticated iterations of the Cochrane risk of bias tools (ROB 2.0 and ROBINS-I).14 15Despite this evidence was generally limited for most outcomes.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: In a network meta-analysis by Gallos et al5 in which different uterotonic options werecompared the authors similarly described inadequate reporting of adverse events in trials of uterotonics for PPH prevention.5 The international consensus statement by Heesen et al8 also called for further large studies on this topic.8 Any such trials should be sufﬁciently powered for important health-related outcomes and should clearly specify the dosing regimen.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Spe- ciﬁcally trials comparing different oxytocin doses of bolus plus infusion regimens should be conducted.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: We consider it particularly important that future trials should report on the outcome of PPH 1000 mL an impor- tant outcome for clinical guideline de- cision making.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: We also found hypotension to be a poorly studied outcome despite dose- dependent hypotension being well described.21 29 42 46 62 Among RCTs the effects of different dosing regimens on hypotension were generally either inconclusive or equivocal.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: No NRSI re- ported signiﬁcant differences in the incidence of hypotension.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: However it would not seem unreasonable to expect an increased incidence of hypotension with higher doses (particularly with bolus regimens) and it is likely that the combination of a bolus plus infusion regimen allows doses to exceed 5 IU while avoiding signiﬁcant hemodynamic instability.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Indeed we consider it particularly important to prioritize research in this area.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: We also did not ﬁnd any clear evidence of diminishing returns from increasing doses and/or longer time periods of infusion despite it also being well described.22 26 Again this was largely because of lack of good-quality data and is an area for which further research is required.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: We identiﬁed a wide range of dosing regimens that added to the complexity of this analysis and likely contributed to high heterogeneity.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Although we aimed to standardize comparisons by using total oxytocin dose we were not able to account for other factors such as rate of oxytocin administration or total infu- sion time.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: We acknowledge that our dose categories are somewhat arbitrary although necessary to standardize andajog.org Systematic Reviews SEPTEMBER 2021 American Journal of Obstetrics & Gynecology 261 interpret comparisons.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: We also tried to minimize the effect of subjective judg- ments on blood loss by including this in our risk of bias assessment and per- forming sensitivity analyses.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Finally the majority of studies included only women undergoing plan- ned CD with low risk of PPH.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Hence these ﬁndings may not be generalizable to other higher-risk groups of women who may require a different oxytocin regimen.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Conclusions and implications Based on current evidence the most appropriate oxytocin regimen may be bolus plus infusion and an initial bolus of <5 IU although further trials are needed to conﬁrm these conclusions.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Bolus only regimens of 10 IU vs 5 IUmay decrease the use of additional utero- tonics however further research is required to understand the implications on adverse events particularly hypoten- sion.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: In the absence of more robust evi- dence many current guidelines on PPH prevention following CD may warrant reconsideration.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Further research is required particularly in women at high risk for PPH for other important out- comes such as adverse maternal events breastfeeding and maternal well-being and satisfaction.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Final conclusion This systematic review and meta- analysis of IV oxytocin dosing regimens for PPH prevention during CDs identi- ﬁed a lack of data for several important outcomes.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Future well-designed studies are required to identify an optimal oxytocin dosing regimen for women undergoing CD.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Nevertheless available data suggest that an IV bolus plus infu- sion regimen with an initial bolus dose of <5 IU may be preferable.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: However the degree of certainty for the evidence was generally low and further research is required to identify the optimal oxytocin regimen for PPH prevention during CDs.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: -ACKNOWLEDGMENTS We would like to acknowledge Patrick Condron (The University of Melbourne Melbourne Australia) for his assistance with the search strategy Dr Rangi de Silva MBBS (Mercy Hos- pital for Women Heidelberg Australia) for her insights on this topic Dr Matthew Page PhD (Monash University Clayton Australia) and Dr Tari Turner PhD (Monash University) for their insights on data analysis and Liz Comrie- Thomson (Burnet Institute Melbourne Australia) for her insights on the entire research process.

text: ajog.org Systematic Reviews SEPTEMBER 2021 American Journal of Obstetrics & Gynecology 263.e2 APPENDIX B Deviations from protocol Protocol Deviation Justiﬁcation Primary outcomes: PPH 500 mL and PPH 1000 mL PPH 500 mL downgraded from primary outcome to secondary outcome We opted to downgrade PPH 500 mL from a primary to a secondary outcome considering that the deﬁnition of PPH after CD is PPH 1000 mL (as distinct from PPH after vaginal birth).

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Included dyspnea and chest pain as additional secondary outcomes Additional adverse events reported in some trials.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Include only third stage administration of oxytocin Included administration of oxytocin at or around third stage Practicality considerations means oxytocin not always able to be delivered at third stage during CD.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Random-effects model if I2 >30% Random-effects model for all analyses with >1 trial Given large heterogeneity of trials and as per Cochrane handbook random-effects model provided a more conservative estimate.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Speciﬁc comparisons made between high dose vs low dose bolus and high dose vs low dose infusion We further divided the comparison of studies into (1) type of IV administration and (2) total oxytocin dose using the categories of <5 IU 5e9 IU 10e19 IU 20e49 IU 50 IU.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Among studies comparing a bolus plus infusion regimen we further compared various initial bolus doses when followed by an infusion.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: The wide range of oxytocin regimens identiﬁed meant that our original approach of high and low dose was not practical nor informative.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: GRADE approach used to rate certainty of evidence.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: More accurately report study ﬁndings and draw conclusions from the data.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Subgroup analysis for studies with maintenance infusions lasting 2e4 h included Explore hypothesis proposed by Heesen et al8 that maintenance infusion should be run for 2e4 h.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: GRADE working group grades of evidence were as follows: High certainty: we are very conﬁdent that the true effect lies close to that of the estimate of the effect.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Moderate certainty: we are moderately conﬁdent in the effect estimate the true effect is likely to be close to the estimate of the effect but there is a possibility that it is substantially different.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Low certainty: our conﬁdence in the effect estimate is limited the true effect may be substantially different from the estimate of the effect.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens
text: Very low certainty: we have very little conﬁdence in the effect estimate the true effect is likely to be substantially different from the estimate of effect.

text: Moderate certainty: we are moderately conﬁdent in the effect estimate the true effect is likely to be close to the estimate of the effect but there is a possibility that it is substantially different.

fname: Intravenous oxytocin dosing regimens

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: Prevention and management of postpartum haemorrhage.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: DOI: 10.1111/1471-0528.14178 Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage This is the second edition of this guideline which was published in 2009 under the same title.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: The 2009 guideline was based on an earlier guideline on the management of postpartum haemorrhage (PPH) developed in 1998 under the auspices of the Scottish Committee of the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists (RCOG) and updated in 2002.1Executive summary of recommendations Prediction and prevention of PPH What are the risk factors for developing PPH and how can they be minimised? Risk factors Risk factors for PPH may present antenatally or intrapartum care plans must be modiﬁed as and when risk factors arise.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: ✓Clinicians must be aware of risk factors for PPH and should take these into account when counselling women about place of delivery.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: ✓Women with known risk factors for PPH should only be delivered in a hospital with a blood bank on site.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: DMinimising risk – treating antenatal anaemia Antenatal anaemia should be investigated and treated appropriately as this may reduce the morbidity associated with PPH.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: [New 2016] DMinimising risk – reducing blood loss at delivery Uterine massage is of no beneﬁt in the prophylaxis of PPH.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: [New 2016] AProphylactic uterotonics should be routinely offered in the management of the third stage of labour in all women as they reduce the risk of PPH.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: ARCOG Green-top Guideline No.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: 52 e107 of e149 ª 2016 Royal College of Obstetricians and GynaecologistsFor women without risk factors for PPH delivering vaginally oxytocin (10 iu by intramuscular injection) is the agent of choice for prophylaxis in the third stage of labour.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: A higher dose of oxytocin is unlikely to be beneﬁcial.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: A For women delivering by caesarean section oxytocin (5 iu by slow intravenous injection) should be used to encourage contraction of the uterus and to decrease blood loss.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: BErgometrine–oxytocin may be used in the absence of hypertension in women at increased risk of haemorrhage as it reduces the risk of minor PPH (500–1000 ml).

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: CFor women at increased risk of haemorrhage it is possible that a combination of preventative measures might be superior to syntocinon alone to prevent PPH.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: [New 2016] ✓Clinicians should consider the use of intravenous tranexamic acid (0.5–1.0 g) in addition to oxytocin at caesarean section to reduce blood loss in women at increased risk of PPH.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: [New 2016] AHow should PPH be managed? Identiﬁcation of the severity of haemorrhage Clinicians should be aware that the visual estimation of peripartum blood loss is inaccurate and that clinical signs and symptoms should be included in the assessment of PPH.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: [New 2016] CCommunication and multidisciplinary care Communication with the woman Communication with the patient and her birthing partner is important and clear information of what is happening should be given from the outset.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: [New 2016] ✓Who should be informed when the woman presents with PPH? Relevant staff with an appropriate level of expertise should be alerted of PPH.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: [New 2016] ✓The midwife in charge and the ﬁrst-line obstetric and anaesthetic staff should be alerted when women present with minor PPH (blood loss 500–1000 ml) without clinical shock.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: ✓A multidisciplinary team involving senior members of staff should be summoned to attend to women with major PPH (blood loss of more than 1000 ml) and ongoing bleeding or clinical shock.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: ✓RCOG Green-top Guideline No.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: 52 e108 of e149 ª 2016 Royal College of Obstetricians and GynaecologistsResuscitation Measures for minor PPH Measures for minor PPH (blood loss 500–1000 ml) without clinical shock: ✓  intravenous access (one 14-gauge cannula)  urgent venepuncture (20 ml) for: – group and screen – full blood count – coagulation screen including ﬁbrinogen  pulse respiratory rate and blood pressure recording every 15 minutes  commence warmed crystalloid infusion.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: Measures for major PPH Full protocol for major PPH (blood loss greater than 1000 ml) and continuing to bleed or clinical shock (see Appendix III):  A and B – assess airway and breathing  C – evaluate circulation  position the patient ﬂat  keep the woman warm using appropriate available measures  transfuse blood as soon as possible if clinically required  until blood is available infuse up to 3.5 l of warmed clear ﬂuids initially 2 l of warmed isotonic crystalloid.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: Further ﬂuid resuscitation can continue with additional isotonic crystalloid or colloid (succinylated gelatin).

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: Hydroxyethyl starch should not be used.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text:  the best equipment available should be used to achieve rapid warmed infusion of ﬂuids  special blood ﬁlters should not be used as they slow infusions.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: Blood transfusion There are no ﬁrm criteria for initiating red cell transfusion.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: The decision to provide blood transfusion should be based on both clinical and haematological assessment.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: [New 2016] ✓Selection of red cell units for transfusion Major obstetric haemorrhage protocols must include the provision of emergency blood with immediate issue of group O rhesus D (RhD)-negative and K-negative units with a switch to group-speciﬁc blood as soon as feasible.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: [New 2016]D If clinically signiﬁcant red cell antibodies are present close liaison with the transfusion laboratory is essential to avoid delay in transfusion in life-threatening haemorrhage.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: [New 2016] D✓ RCOG Green-top Guideline No.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: 52 e109 of e149 ª 2016 Royal College of Obstetricians and GynaecologistsAll delivery units especially small units without a blood bank on site should maintain a supply of group O RhD-negative blood.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: [New 2016] ✓Intraoperative cell salvage should be considered for emergency use in PPH associated with caesarean section and with vaginal delivery.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: [New 2016] DBlood components Transfusion of fresh frozen plasma (FFP) If no haemostatic results are available and bleeding is continuing then after 4 units of red blood cells FFP should be infused at a dose of 12–15 ml/kg until haemostatic test results are known.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: [New 2016]D If no haemostatic tests are available early FFP should be considered for conditions with a suspected coagulopathy such as placental abruption or amniotic ﬂuid embolism or where detection of PPH has been delayed.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: [New 2016]✓ If prothrombin time/activated partial thromboplastin time is more than 1.5 times normal and haemorrhage is ongoing volumes of FFP in excess of 15 ml/kg are likely to be needed to correct coagulopathy.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: [New 2016]D Clinicians should be aware that these blood components must be ordered as soon as a need for them is anticipated as there will always be a short delay in supply because of the need for thawing.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: [New 2016]✓ Fibrinogen A plasma ﬁbrinogen level of greater than 2 g/l should be maintained during ongoing PPH.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: [New 2016] CCryoprecipitate should be used for ﬁbrinogen replacement.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: [New 2016] DTransfusion of platelets During PPH platelets should be transfused when the platelet count is less than 75 3 109/l based on laboratory monitoring.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: [New 2016] DIs there a role for antiﬁbrinolytic drugs? Consideration should be given to the use of tranexamic acid in the management of PPH.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: [New 2016] BRCOG Green-top Guideline No.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: 52 e110 of e149 ª 2016 Royal College of Obstetricians and GynaecologistsIs there a role for recombinant factor VIIa (rFVIIa) therapy? The routine use of rFVIIa is not recommended in the management of major PPH unless as part of a clinical trial.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: [New 2016] ✓Monitoring and investigation in major PPH: what investigations should be performed and how should women be monitored? Full protocol for monitoring and investigation in major PPH (blood loss greater than 1000 ml) and ongoing haemorrhage or clinical shock:  immediate venepuncture (20 ml) for: – cross-match (4 units minimum) – full blood count – coagulation screen including ﬁbrinogen – renal and liver function for baseline  monitor temperature every 15 minutes  continuous pulse blood pressure recording and respiratory rate (using oximeter electrocardiogram and automated blood pressure recording)  Foley catheter to monitor urine output  two peripheral cannulae 14 gauge  consider arterial line monitoring (once appropriately experienced staff available for insertion)  consider transfer to intensive therapy unit once the bleeding is controlled or monitoring at high dependency unit on delivery suite if appropriate  recording of parameters on a modiﬁed early obstetric warning score (MEOWS) chart (see Appendix IV)  acting and escalating promptly when abnormal scores from a MEOWS chart are observed  documentation of ﬂuid balance blood blood products and procedures.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: What is the role of the anaesthetist in the management of PPH? The management of PPH requires a multidisciplinary approach: the anaesthetist plays a crucial role in maintaining haemodynamic stability and if necessary in determining and administering the most appropriate method of anaesthesia.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: [New 2016]D What methods should be employed to arrest the bleeding? Clinicians should be prepared to use a combination of pharmacological mechanical and surgical methods to arrest PPH.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: These methods should be directed towards the causative factor.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: [New 2016] DWhat pharmacological and mechanical strategies can be used? When uterine atony is perceived to be a cause of the bleeding then a sequence of mechanical and pharmacological measures should be instituted in turn until the bleeding stops.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: ✓D RCOG Green-top Guideline No.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: 52 e111 of e149 ª 2016 Royal College of Obstetricians and GynaecologistsWhat surgical treatments can be employed to arrest the bleeding? If pharmacological measures fail to control the haemorrhage surgical interventions should be initiated sooner rather than later.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: DIntrauterine balloon tamponade is an appropriate ﬁrst-line ‘surgical’ intervention for most women where uterine atony is the only or main cause of haemorrhage.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: CConservative surgical interventions may be attempted as second line depending on clinical circumstances and available expertise.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: CIt is recommended that a laminated diagram of the brace suture technique be kept in theatre.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: ✓Resort to hysterectomy sooner rather than later (especially in cases of placenta accreta or uterine rupture).

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: CIdeally and when feasible a second experienced clinician should be involved in the decision for hysterectomy.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: ✓How should secondary PPH be managed? In women presenting with secondary PPH an assessment of vaginal microbiology should be performed (high vaginal and endocervical swabs) and appropriate use of antimicrobial therapy should be initiated when endometritis is suspected.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: [New 2016]D A pelvic ultrasound may help to exclude the presence of retained products of conception although the diagnosis of retained products is unreliable.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: [New 2016] CSurgical evacuation of retained placental tissue should be undertaken or supervised by an experienced clinician.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: DRisk management Training and preparation: what measures can be taken to ensure optimal management of PPH? Every maternity unit should have a multidisciplinary protocol for the management of PPH.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: [New 2016] ✓All staff involved in maternity care should receive training in the management of obstetric emergencies including the management of PPH.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: BTraining for PPH should be multiprofessional and include team rehearsals.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: [New 2016] BAll cases of PPH involving a blood loss of greater than 1500 ml should be the subject of a formal clinical incident review.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: DRCOG Green-top Guideline No.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: 52 e112 of e149 ª 2016 Royal College of Obstetricians and GynaecologistsDocumentation Accurate documentation of a delivery with PPH is essential.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: ✓Debrieﬁng An opportunity to discuss the events surrounding the obstetric haemorrhage should be offered to the woman (possibly with her birthing partner/s) at a mutually convenient time.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: Purpose and scopePrimary postpartum haemorrhage (PPH) is the most common form of major obstetric haemorrhage.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: The traditional deﬁnition of primary PPH is the loss of 500 ml or more of blood from the genital tract within 24 hours of the birth of a baby.2 PPH can be minor (500–1000 ml) or major (more than 1000 ml).

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: Major can be further subdivided into moderate (1001–2000 ml) and severe (more than 2000 ml).

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: In women with lower body mass (e.g.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: less than 60 kg) a lower level of blood loss may be clinically signiﬁcant.3 The recommendations in this guideline apply to women experiencing a primary PPH of 500 ml or more.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: Secondary PPH is deﬁned as abnormal or excessive bleeding from the birth canal between 24 hours and 12 weeks postnatally.4 This guideline also includes recommendations speciﬁc to the management of secondary PPH.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: Women with pre-existing bleeding disorders and women taking therapeutic anticoagulants are at increased risk of PPH this guideline does not include speciﬁc recommendations for the management of such situations or for managing haemorrhage in women who refuse blood transfusion.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: Guidance on these topics is available from other sources.5–8This guideline has been developed primarily for clinicians working in consultant-led obstetric units in the UK recommendations may be less appropriate for other settings where facilities resources and routine practices differ.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: There is increasing emphasis on the availability of births at home or in midwife-led units.9 Obstetricians and midwives should develop guidelines for the management of obstetric emergencies that may occur in the community including PPH.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: This is beyond the scope of this guideline.10This guideline is restricted in scope to the management of PPH the management of antepartum haemorrhage is the subject of the RCOG Green-top Guideline No.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: 63.11 The prevention and management of PPH related to placenta praevia and placenta praevia accreta is addressed in Green-top Guideline No.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: 27 12 while Green-top Guideline No.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: 4713provides guidance on the appropriate use of blood and blood products in obstetric practice.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: Introduction and background epidemiologyObstetric haemorrhage remains one of the major causes of maternal death in both developed and developing countries.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: The 2011–13 Conﬁdential Enquiries into Maternal Deaths and Morbidity report3 identiﬁed 13 direct deaths due to obstetric haemorrhage in the UK and Ireland the report places obstetric haemorrhage as the second leading cause of direct maternal deaths.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: The recommendations from the report focus on basic clinical skills with prompt recognition of the severity of a haemorrhage and emphasise communication and teamwork in the management of these cases.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: A systematic review14 suggests that there may be regional variation in the prevalence of PPH.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: Standardisation of the measurement of PPH is recommended so that data from different regions are comparable.15RCOG Green-top Guideline No.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: 52 e113 of e149 ª 2016 Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists3.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: Identiﬁcation and assessment of evidenceThis guideline was developed in accordance with standard methodology for producing RCOG Green-top Guidelines.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: The Cochrane Library (including the Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews and the Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects [DARE]) EMBASE Trip MEDLINE and PubMed (electronic databases) were searched for relevant randomised controlled trials systematic reviews and meta-analyses.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: The search was restricted to articles published between 2007 and September 2015.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: The databases were searched using the relevant Medical Subject Headings (MeSH) terms including all subheadings and this was combined with a keyword search.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: Search words included ‘postpartum h(a)emorrhage’ ‘factor VII’ ‘Syntocinon’ ‘carbetocin’ ‘carboprost’ ‘oxytocics’ ‘uterotonics’ ‘B-lynch suture’ ‘uterine artery embolism’ ‘bilateral internal iliac ligation’ ‘balloon Rusch’ ‘Sengstaken catheters’ ‘thromboelastography’ ‘thromboelastometry’ ‘ﬁbrinogen concentrate’ ‘point of care testing’ and the search limited to humans and the English language.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: The National Library for Health and the National Guideline Clearinghouse were also searched for relevant guidelines and reviews.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: Guidelines and recommendations produced by organisations such as the British Committee for Standards in Haematology Transfusion Taskforce and national bodies were considered.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: Where possible recommendations are based on available evidence and the areas where evidence is lacking are annotated as ‘good practice points’.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: Further information about the assessment of evidence and the grading of recommendations may be found in Appendix I.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: Prediction and prevention of PPH4.1 What are the risk factors for developing PPH and how can they be minimised? 4.1.1 Risk factors Risk factors for PPH may present antenatally or intrapartum care plans must be modiﬁed as and when risk factors arise.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: ✓Clinicians must be aware of risk factors for PPH and should take these into account when counselling women about place of delivery.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: ✓Women with known risk factors for PPH should only be delivered in a hospital with a blood bank on site.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: DA number of case–control studies have identiﬁed antenatal and intrapartum risk factors for PPH (see Appendix II) 16–26 although most cases of PPH have no identiﬁable risk factors.27 These risk factors have been summarised in a 2010 review.28 Despite methodological limitations these studies provide a guide to levels of risk which can help clinicians in their discussions with women about setting for delivery (Table 1).

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: The Conﬁdential Enquiry into Maternal and Child Health29 has recommended that women with known risk factors for PPH should not be delivered in a hospital without a blood bank on site.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: The Society of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists of Canada has published a guideline on the prevention and management of PPH.30 This summarises the causes of PPH as related to abnormalities of one or more of four basic processes – ‘the four Ts’: tone trauma tissue and thrombin.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: The most common cause of PPH is uterine atony.27Evidence level 4 RCOG Green-top Guideline No.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: 52 e114 of e149 ª 2016 Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists4.1.2 Minimising risk – treating antenatal anaemia Antenatal anaemia should be investigated and treated appropriately as this may reduce the morbidity associated with PPH.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: DGuidelines from the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE)32 recommend that pregnant women should be offered screening for anaemia.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: The British Committee for Standards in Haematology33has produced guidelines on the investigation and management of anaemia in pregnancy.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: Haemoglobin (Hb) levels outside the normal UK range for pregnancy (110 g/l at ﬁrst contact and 105 g/l at 28 weeks) should be investigated and iron supplementation considered if indicated.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: It is recommended that parenteral iron therapy should be considered antenatally for women with iron deﬁciency anaemia who do not respond to oral iron.10Evidence level 4 A population-based study34 has indicated an association between antenatal anaemia (Hb less than 90 g/l) and greater blood loss at delivery and postpartum.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: Evidence level 3 Table 1.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: Risk factors and the associated levels of risk for PPHRisk factor The four Ts OR (95% CI) Multiple pregnancy Tone 3.30 (1.00–10.60)16 4.70 (2.40–9.10)24 Previous PPH Tone 3.60 (1.20–10.20)16 Pre-eclampsia Thrombin 5.00 (3.00–8.50)16 2.20 (1.30–3.70)31 Fetal macrosomia Tone 2.11 (1.62–2.76)20 2.40 (1.90–2.90)24 Failure to progress in second stage Tone 3.40 (2.40–4.70)23 1.90 (1.20–2.90)31 Prolonged third stage of labour Tone 7.60 (4.20–13.50)16 2.61 (1.83–3.72)20 Retained placenta Tissue 7.83 (3.78–16.22)20 3.50 (2.10–5.80)23 6.00 (3.50–10.40)24 Placenta accreta Tissue 3.30 (1.70–6.40)23 Episiotomy Trauma 4.70 (2.60–8.40)16 2.18 (1.68–2.76)20 1.70 (1.20–2.50)24 Perineal laceration Trauma 1.40 (1.04–1.87)20 2.40 (2.00–2.80)23 1.70 (1.10–2.50)24 General anaesthesia Tone 2.90 (1.90–4.50)31 RCOG Green-top Guideline No.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: 52 e115 of e149 ª 2016 Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists4.1.3 Minimising risk – reducing blood loss at delivery Uterine massage is of no beneﬁt in the prophylaxis of PPH.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: AProphylactic uterotonics should be routinely offered in the management of the third stage of labour in all women as they reduce the risk of PPH.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: AFor women without risk factors for PPH delivering vaginally oxytocin (10 iu by intramuscular injection) is the agent of choice for prophylaxis in the third stage of labour.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: A higher dose of oxytocin is unlikely to be beneﬁcial.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: A For women delivering by caesarean section oxytocin (5 iu by slow intravenous injection) should be used to encourage contraction of the uterus and to decrease blood loss.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: BErgometrine–oxytocin may be used in the absence of hypertension in women at increased risk of haemorrhage as it reduces the risk of minor PPH (500–1000 ml).

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: CFor women at increased risk of haemorrhage it is possible that a combination of preventative measures might be superior to syntocinon alone to prevent PPH.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: ✓Clinicians should consider the use of intravenous tranexamic acid (0.5–1.0 g) in addition to oxytocin at caesarean section to reduce blood loss in women at increased risk of PPH.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: AUterine massage A Cochrane review35 analysed the effectiveness of uterine massage after birth and before or after delivery of the placenta or both to prevent PPH.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: Two randomised controlled trials (RCTs) were included and the review found no signiﬁcant difference between groups.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: Evidence level 1+ Management of the third stage of labour Various Cochrane reviews have addressed prophylaxis in the third stage of labour for women delivering vaginally.35–38 These have established that both active management and the use of prophylactic uterotonics in the third stage of labour reduce the risk of PPH.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: Active management of the third stage of labour involves the use of interventions (including the use of uterotonics early clamping of the umbilical cord and controlled cord traction) to expedite delivery of the placenta with the aim of reducing blood loss.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: In expectant management signs of placental separation are awaited and the placenta is delivered spontaneously.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
