text: Uterotonics such as misoprostol and ergometrine have been recommended in the management of secondary PPH although evidence to support their use is limited.178 Transcatheter arterial embolisation193 and balloon tamponade194 have been employed in cases of secondary PPH with ongoing bleeding.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: Evidence level 3 7.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: Risk management7.1 Training and preparation: what measures can be taken to ensure optimal management of PPH? Every maternity unit should have a multidisciplinary protocol for the management of PPH.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: ✓All staff involved in maternity care should receive training in the management of obstetric emergencies including the management of PPH.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: BTraining for PPH should be multiprofessional and include team rehearsals.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: BAll cases of PPH involving a blood loss of greater than 1500 ml should be the subject of a formal clinical incident review.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: DTo ensure optimal management of PPH every unit should have a multidisciplinary protocol with which staff should be familiar (see section 5).

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: Updates on the management of obstetric emergencies (including the management of PPH) are a proactive approach to risk management.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: Skills drills should ensure that all members of staff including those working in the transfusion laboratory are aware of their role in the management of PPH.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: A systematic review195 of the effectiveness of multidisciplinary simulation training in obstetric emergencies (including PPH) showed that teamwork training in a simulation setting resulted in improvement of knowledge practical skills communication and team performance.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: Training in a simulation centre did not further improve outcome compared with training at a local unit.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: Evidence level 2++ The RCOG recommends that all cases of PPH with an estimated blood loss of more than 1500 ml should be the subject of a formal clinical incident review.196 Evidence level 4 RCOG Green-top Guideline No.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: 52 e136 of e149 ª 2016 Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists7.2 Documentation Accurate documentation of a delivery with PPH is essential.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: ✓Accurate documentation is important for further clinical management continuity of care and team work.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: In addition inadequate documentation can contribute to the likelihood of there being medicolegal consequences.197 The team member recording events on the structured proforma the scribe is crucial in the management of PPH (see Appendix V) the proforma is effectively a checklist of available interventions and team leaders should communicate with the scribe during the PPH to ensure that no steps have been omitted.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: PPH should be notiﬁed through a clinical incident reporting or risk management system.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: Evidence level 4 It is important to record:  the staff in attendance and the time they arrived  the sequence of events  the administration of different pharmacological agents their timing and sequence  the time of surgical intervention where relevant  the condition of the mother throughout the different steps  the timing of the ﬂuid and blood products given.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: 7.3 Debrieﬁng An opportunity to discuss the events surrounding the obstetric haemorrhage should be offered to the woman (possibly with her birthing partner/s) at a mutually convenient time.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: ✓After obstetric emergencies women can be psychologically affected by postnatal depression or fear of further childbirth.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: Major PPH can be traumatic to women and their families and has been associated with the subsequent development of post-traumatic stress disorder.198 Women who have experienced a major PPH should be offered an opportunity to discuss the events surrounding their delivery.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: A discussion of future pregnancy including the likelihood of a repeat PPH and any fears regarding pregnancy and childbirth that the woman may have should be addressed.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: This should include arrangements for appropriate investigations as necessary such as testing for coagulopathies if there are other indicators and screening for the rare complication of postpartum hypopituitarism (Sheehan syndrome) secondary to hypotension.199Evidence level 4 8.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: Recommendations for future research RCTs are required to identify the best drug combinations route and dose of uterotonics for the treatment of primary PPH.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text:  The role of viscoelastometric point of care tests using TEG and ROTEM in the management of PPH requires evaluation.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text:  Studies are required to determine the optimal ratio of packed red cells to FFP in the management of obstetric haemorrhage.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: RCOG Green-top Guideline No.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: 52 e137 of e149 ª 2016 Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists Studies are required to determine the role of ﬁbrinogen concentrate in the management of PPH.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text:  The role of prothrombin complex concentrate in the management of PPH requires evaluation.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text:  RCTs are required to investigate the role of uterotonic agents (misoprostol and ergometrine) in the management of secondary PPH.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: 52 e143 of e149 ª 2016 Royal College of Obstetricians and GynaecologistsAppendix I: Explanation of guidelines and evidence levels Clinical guidelines are: ‘systematically developed statements which assist clinicians and patients in making decisions about appropriate treatment for speciﬁc conditions’.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: Each guideline is systematically developed using a standardised methodology.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: Exact details of this process can be found in Clinical Governance Advice No.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: 1 Development of RCOG Green-top Guidelines (available on the RCOG website at www.rcog.org.uk/green-top-development).

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: These recommendations are not intended to dictate an exclusive course of management or treatment.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: They must be evaluated with reference to individual patient needs resources and limitations unique to the institution and variations in local populations.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: It is hoped that this process of local ownership will help to incorporate these guidelines into routine practice.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: Attention is drawn to areas of clinical uncertainty where further research may be indicated.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: The evidence used in this guideline was graded using the scheme below and the recommendations formulated in a similar fashion with a standardised grading scheme.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: Classiﬁcation of evidence levels Grades of recommendations 1++ High-quality meta-analyses systematic reviews of randomised controlled trials or randomised controlled trials with a very low risk of bias A At least one meta-analysis systematic reviews or RCT rated as 1++ and directly applicable to the target population or A systematic review of RCTs or a body of evidence consisting principally of studies rated as 1+ directly applicable to the target population and demonstrating overall consistency of results 1+ Well-conducted meta-analyses systematic reviews of randomised controlled trials or randomised controlled trials with a low risk of bias 1– Meta-analyses systematic reviews of randomised controlled trials or randomised controlled trials with a high risk of bias B A body of evidence including studies rated as 2++ directly applicable to the target population and demonstrating overall consistency of results or Extrapolated evidence from studies rated as 1++ or 1+ 2++ High-quality systematic reviews of case–control or cohort studies or high-quality case–control or cohort studies with a very low risk of confounding bias or chance and a high probability that the relationship is causal 2+ Well-conducted case–control or cohort studies with a low risk of confounding bias or chance and a moderate probability that the relationship is causal C A body of evidence including studies rated as 2+ directly applicable to the target population and demonstrating overall consistency of results or Extrapolated evidence from studies rated as 2++ 2– Case–control or cohort studies with a high risk of confounding bias or chance and a signiﬁcant risk that the relationship is not causal 3 Non-analytical studies e.g.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: case reports case seriesD Evidence level 3 or 4 or Extrapolated evidence from studies rated as 2+ 4 Expert opinion Good practice point ✓ Recommended best practice based on the clinical experience of the guideline development group RCOG Green-top Guideline No.

text: 52 e145 of e149 ª 2016 Royal College of Obstetricians and GynaecologistsAppendix III: A ﬂow chart of the different steps for the management of major PPH Resuscitation monitoring investigation and treatment should occur simultaneously Major obstetric haemorrhage Blood loss greater than 1000 ml Continuing major obstetric haemorrhage or clinical shock Call for help Senior midwife/obstetrician and anaesthetist Alert haematologist Alert blood transfusion laboratory Alert consultant obstetrician on call Resuscitation Airway Breathing Circulation Oxygen mask (15 l) Fluid balance (e.g.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: 2 l isotonic crystalloid 1.5 l colloid) Blood transfusion (O RhD-negative or group-specific blood) Blood products (FFP PLT cryoprecipitate factor VIIa) Keep patient warmTheatre Is the uterus contracted? Examination under anaesthesia Has any clotting abnormality been corrected? Intrauterine balloon tamponade Brace suture Consider interventional radiology Monitoring and investigations 14-gauge cannula x 2 FBC coagulation U&Es LFTs Cross-match (4 units FFP PLT  cryoprecipitate) ECG oximeter Foley catheter Hb bedside testing Blood products Consider central and arterial lines Commence record chart Weigh all swabs and estimate blood loss Medical treatment Rub up the uterine fundus Empty bladder Oxytocin 5 iu slow IV (repeat if necessary) Ergometrine 0.5 mg slow IV or IM Oxytocin infusion (40 iu in 500 ml) Carboprost 0.25 mg IM every 15 minutes up to 8 times Carboprost (intramyometrial) 0.5 mg Misoprostol 800 micrograms sublingually Consider tranexamic acid 1 g IV Surgery Stepwise uterine devascularisation Bilateral internal iliac ligation Hysterectomy (second experienced clinician) Uterine artery embolisation High-dependency unit or intensive care unit Abbreviations: ECG electrocardiogram FBC full blood count FFP fresh frozen plasma Hb haemoglobin IV intravenous IM intramuscular LFTs liver function tests PLT platelets PPH postpartum haemorrhage RhD rhesus D U&Es urea and electrolytes.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: DISCLAIMER The Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists produces guidelines as an educational aid to good clinical practice.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: They present recognised methods and techniques of clinical practice based on published evidence for consideration by obstetricians and gynaecologists and other relevant health professionals.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: The ultimate judgement regarding a particular clinical procedure or treatment plan must be made by the doctor or other attendant in the light of clinical data presented by the patient and the diagnostic and treatment options available.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: This means that RCOG Guidelines are unlike protocols or guidelines issued by employers as they are not intended to be prescriptive directions deﬁning a single course of management.

fname: Prevention and Management of Postpartum Haemorrhage
text: Departure from the local prescriptive protocols or guidelines should be fully documented in the patient’s case notes at the time the relevant decision is taken.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: 9 LT-44307 Kaunas Lithuania migle.vitartaite@stud.lsmu.lt * Correspondence: vilda.baliuliene@lsmuni.lt Tel.: +370-67-267569Abstract: Objective—to overview compare and generalize results of randomized clinical trials an- alyzing different oxytocin doses to prevent postpartum hemorrhage initiate and maintain uterine contraction after Caesarean delivery.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Methods—‘PubMed’ ‘EMBASE’ ‘CENTRAL’ and ‘CINAHL’ electronic databases were searched for clinical trials analyzing the effectiveness of different dose of oxytocin given intravenously during surgery for uterine contraction and to reduce postpartum hemorrhage.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: A systematic review of relevant literature sources was performed.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Results—our search revealed 813 literature sources.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: A total of 15 randomized clinical trials comparing different doses of oxytocin bolus and infusion used after caesarean delivery have met the selection criteria.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Conclusion—oxytocin bolus 0.5–3 UI is considered an effective prophylactic dose.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Recommended effective prophylactic oxytocin infusion dose is 7.72 IU/h but it is unanswered whether we really need a prophylactic infusion of oxytocin if we choose effective bolus dose size and rate.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Adverse hemodynamic effects were observed when a 5 UI oxytocin bolus was used.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: However topics such as bolus dose size infusion dose size and requirement as well as bolus injection rate still remain unanswered.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: The doses that are recommended in the guidelines of peripartum hemorrhage prophy- laxis are not conﬁrmed by randomized controlled double-blind trials and more research should cover this topic.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Keywords: oxytocin uterine contraction caesarean delivery hemorrhage 1.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: IntroductionEarly postpartum hemorrhage can occur if oxytocin is not used or if the dose of its bolus or infusion is too small.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologist deﬁnes early (primary) postpartum hemorrhage as at 1000 mL or more of total blood loss or loss of blood accompanied by signs and symptoms of hypovolemia within 24 h following the delivery including intrapartum loss [1].

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: The Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists divides it into minor (500–1000 mL) and major (1000 mL and more) categories.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: They also deﬁne late (secondary) postpartum hemorrhage as abnormal or excessive bleeding later than 24 h post-birth but no later than 12 weeks [2].

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Parturient hemorrhage has been the main cause of maternal morbidity and mortality for many years all over the world.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Postpartum hemorrhage is one of the most common complications after caesarean delivery which is an important surgical intervention performed in obstetric practice.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: This has to be considered because caesarean delivery rates in the developing world countries keep getting higher [3 4].

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Minimizing the amount of blood lost during caesarean delivery has a great beneﬁt to decrease postoperative morbidity and to decrease the risks associated with blood transfusions.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: The routine use of oxytocin correlates with a signiﬁcant reduction in the occurrence of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) [5–7].

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Finding an optimal dose of oxytocin in patients undergoing caesarean delivery is a problem of great importance because it is mandatory to achieve an adequate balance be-Int.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: The aim of this review was to analyze the randomized controlled trials and to ﬁnd the best and lowest possible prophylactic dose of oxytocin during caesarean delivery (CD).

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: MethodsThe design of this systematic review of the literature is followed by the Preferred Re- porting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) statement guidelines.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Data were identiﬁed from searches of MEDLINE (PubMed) Excerpta Medica Database (EMBASE) Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL) Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature (CINAHL) databases and conducted up to the 15 November 2020.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: The combination of keywords included terms ‘oxytocin’ and ‘caesarean’ and ‘dose’ or ‘hemorrhage’ in PubMed Advanced Search Builder in all ﬁelds accordance with the PICO criteria: ‘participants’ were limited to pregnant women ‘interventions’ covered were randomized controlled clinical trials on caesarean delivery ‘comparator’—comparing oxytocin with placebo or a different dose of oxytocin ‘outcomes’ discovered after a thor- ough analysis of researches and classiﬁed into categories according to the trial type and most common ﬁndings.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Records were screened by the title abstract and full text by two independent investigators (V.B.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: and M.V.).

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Any disagreements were resolved through evaluation and discussion or by consulting a third independent investigator who made the ﬁnal decision.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Inclusion criteria were: (1) full text articles published in English (2) not older than 2004 (3) single double or triple-blinded randomized trials of different oxytocin intravenous dosage and/or placebo (4) caesarean delivery (5) aged over 18.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: However we review or meta-analyze systematic review articles commentaries abstract-only publi- cations guidelines case reports trials with oxytocin and carbetocin other than oxytocin uterotonic agent but not randomized trials and dose-ranging trials were excluded.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: The detailed search ﬂowchart is presented in Figure 1.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: I t J E vi o es u ic ea t 0  8 o 3   Finding an optimal dose of oxytocin in patients undergoing caesarean delivery is a problem of great importance because it is mandatory to achieve an adequate balance be- tween effective uterine contraction to limit postpartum hemorrhage and oxytocin-induced adverse events.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: The aim of this review was to analyze the randomized controlled trials and to find the best and lowest possible prophylactic dose of oxytocin during caesarean delivery (CD).

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: MethodsThe design of this systematic review of the literature is followed by the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) statement guide- lines.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Data were identified from searches of MEDLINE (PubMed) Excerpta Medica Data- base (EMBASE) Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL) Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature (CINAHL) databases and conducted up to the 15 November 2020.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: The combination of keywords included terms ‘oxytocin’ and ‘cae- sarean’ and ‘dose’ or ‘hemorrhage’ in PubMed Advanced Search Builder in all fields ac- cordance with the PICO criteria: ‘participants’ were limited to pregnant women ‘inter- ventions’ covered were randomized controlled clinical trials on caesarean delivery ‘com- parator’—comparing oxytocin with placebo or a different dose of oxytocin ‘outcomes’ discovered after a thorough analysis of researches and classified into categories according to the trial type and most common findings.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Records were screened by the title abstract and full text by two independent investigators (V.B.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: and M.V.).

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Any disagreements were resolved through evaluation and discussion or by consulting a third independent investi- gator who made the final decision.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Inclusion criteria were: (1) full text articles published in English (2) not older than 2004 (3) single double or triple-blinded randomized trials of different oxytocin intravenous dosage and/or placebo (4) caesarean delivery (5) aged over 18.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: However we review or meta-analyze systematic review articles commentaries  abstract-only publications guidelines case reports trials with oxytocin and carbetocin  other than oxytocin uterotonic agent but not randomized trials and dose-ranging trials were excluded.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Results 3.1.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Study Selection ProcessThe research yielded 813 results extracted from one database.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: All duplicates were removed 526 articles were checked manually for relevance by screening their titles and abstracts.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: A total 120 results met the inclusion criteria but only 15 were included after a full-text review.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Only full-text articles were selected because the information given in the abstract was not sufﬁcient for the thorough analysis.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: The randomized trials conducted in 2008–2020 which compared different doses of oxytocin or oxytocin and placebo given for patients during CD in order to investigate the effect of the drug on PPH and uterine contraction were analyzed.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: A total of 105 publications were excluded for reasons explained in Picture 1.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Characteristics of Included StudiesThose 15 selected trials could be divided into several groups: those that investigate different bolus dose (5 trials) those that investigate different infusion dose (9 trials) and those that investigate both (1 trial).

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: A summary of the results of 15 analyzed studies is provided in Table 1.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Synthesis of ResultsAll 15 trials (bolus/infusion/both) included in this systematic review were investi- gated and compared in 4 categories: PPH and blood loss uterine contraction and hemody- namics.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: The summarized results can be seen in Table 2.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Butwick and colleagues compared 75 women divided into 5 groups to receive 0 0.5 1 3 or 5 IU oxytocin bolus intravenously diluted with 5 mL of 0.9% normal saline and administered over the time period of 15 s.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Adequate uterine tonus was measured at 2 3 6 and 9 min.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: There were no signiﬁcant differences of adequate uterine tonus at 2 min between the groups.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Sixty-six per cent of participants in the placebo group had adequate uterine tonus at 3 min and 100% of the parturient receiving 3 IU of oxytocin (p = 0.04).

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: This study results indicated that adequate uterine tonus for patients during caesarean delivery can be achieved using a small 0.5–3 IU bolus of oxytocin plus continuous infusion of 250 mL normal saline with 10 IU of oxytocin [8].

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Sartain with co-authors studied data of 80 women who were given 2 IU or 5 IU oxytocin bolus over 5–10 s and oxytocin infusion of at rate 10 IU/h for 4 h (40 IU totally) after delivery.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: No difference was found in blood loss uterine tone or need for additional uterotonic drugs.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Nonetheless heart rate was found higher mean arterial pressure was found smaller and frequency of nausea and antiemetic drugs were bigger in the 5 IU oxytocin bolus group [9].

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Somjit and co-authors compared 5 IU and 10 IU oxytocin bolus infused over 15 s and followed by the infusion with 20 IU of oxytocin (2.5 IU/h) impact on uterine contraction.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Fewer patients who received 10 IU oxytocin bolus needed additional uterotonic agents.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Blood loss and the uterine tone did not differ signiﬁcantly.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: They concluded that 5 IU was non-inferior to 10 IU oxytocin [10].

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: King with co-authors investigated the impact of 5 IU oxytocin bolus injected over 30 s on women who have at least one risk factor for uterine atony.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: One hundred and forty-three participants were divided into 2 groups: one group received 5 IU oxytocin bolus followed by 40 IU in 500 mL and 20 IU in 1 L saline oxytocin infusions and the second were given placebo bolus.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: The number of women requiring an additional dose of uterotonic agents was similar in both groups.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: They found a signiﬁcant difference in uterine tone after delivery which was bigger in the group who received 5 IU oxytocin bolus (p < 0.001).

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: However this result was transient and disappeared after 5 min.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Therefore this study revealed that there is no difference in PPH between women who receive oxytocin bolus and those who do not [11].

text: Public Health 2021 18 5029 8 of 14Jonsson with colleagues investigated 5 and 10 IU of oxytocin IV bolus injected over 1 min impact on electrocardiography.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Further doses of uterotonic drugs were available upon request.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: They found a signiﬁcant difference in the occurrence of ST depressions associated with oxytocin administration.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: The conclusion was that 5 IU has less effect on changes in ECG [12].

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Kovacheva and colleagues from Boston conducted a study where one group of 30 women received 3 IU oxytocin bolus (over 15 s) and 500 mL saline infusion and the other group of the same size were given placebo bolus and 30 IU oxytocin in 500 mL infusion.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Both groups received additional oxytocin according to uterine tone assessed between 3 min and 12 min if necessary.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Women who received oxytocin bolus also received less oxytocin overall to achieve adequate uterine tone.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: No differences in hemodynamic or blood loss occurred [13].

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Cecilia and colleagues conducted a trial of 271 women randomized into 2 groups: the ﬁrst group received 10 IU of oxytocin in 500 mL of ﬂuids over 2–4 h while the second group was given 30 IU of oxytocin in 1500 mL of ﬂuids over 8–12 h.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: The atonic uterus was seen in 1 patient from the ﬁrst group and 7 women from the second group (p = 0.03).

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Postoperative fall in blood pressure tachycardia and amount of blood loss during the operation and postoperative period and blood transfusions were similar between groups.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: The conclusion was that a low-dose oxytocin regimen is as effective as a high-dose oxytocin regimen in the prevention of PPH in the postoperative period after caesarean delivery [14].

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Ghulmiyyah and colleagues randomly assigned 189 patients into 3 groups where women received 20 30 or 40 IU of oxytocin in 500 mL solution over 30 min.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: No signiﬁcant difference in the change of hemoglobin concentration was observed.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: This implies that 20 IU oxytocin diluted in 500 mL solution is an appropriate dose for the prevention of PPH [15].

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Dufﬁeld with colleagues included 51 women: 24 patients received 10 IU of oxytocin in 1 L solution and 27 received 60 IU of oxytocin in 1 L solution.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Additional bolus doses of 1 IU oxytocin were given after evaluating uterine contraction between 2 min and 20 min at 2 min intervals if requested.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: They did not observe any statistically signiﬁcant difference in excessive blood loss between groups concluding that both low and high infusion of oxytocin works in the same preventive regime [16].

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Gungorduk and co-authors investigated 360 women who were given 5 IU of oxytocin bolus (over 5–10 s) and consecutive infusion with placebo and other 360 participants re- ceived 5 IU of oxytocin bolus and consecutive infusion of 30 IU of oxytocin.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Mean estimated blood loss (p < 0.001) greater than 1000 mL were signiﬁcantly less in the group of patients who were given 30 IU oxytocin infusion.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: More women in the placebo group required an additional uterotonic agent (p < 0.001) and blood transfusion (p = 0.03).

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: This study revealed that 30 IU oxytocin infusion given after bolus lowers the blood loss after CD [17].

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Kajendran with other researchers aimed to ﬁnd out the difference in blood loss between two groups of patients who were given 5 IU oxytocin bolus over 5–10 and 46 were given 20 IU oxytocin in 500 mL saline and the other half were given just 500 mL saline later.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: The blood loss in the group of 20 IU oxytocin infusion was signiﬁcantly less (p = 0.046).

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Visual estimation of blood loss made by the surgeon (p = 0.01) and anesthetist (p = 0.03) was also signiﬁcantly higher in the placebo group [18].

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: McLeod studied hemodynamic differences between 2 groups of women: both groups were given 5 UI oxytocin bolus over 3 min and 39 patients received 30 UI oxytocin infusion or 35 women were given placebo infusion.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: There were no signiﬁcant differences between groups during the 4-h study period.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: An additional oxytocin infusion after the bolus does not have a signiﬁcant impact on patient hemodynamic [19].

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Murphy with other scientists compared the blood loss of 110 women divided in the same 2 groups as McLeod did.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: They favored the group with oxytocin infusion be- cause the blood loss was lower PPH occurred rarely and almost none needed additional uterotonic agent [20].

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Sheehan with co-authors conducted a study of 2058 women who received 5 IU bolus over 1 min but half of them were given 40 IU oxytocin infusion ant others wereInt.

text: No difference was found in PPH between groups (p = 0.86).

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: There was a signiﬁcant difference in uterotonic agent need it was higher in the placebo group (p < 0.001) [21].

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Qian and others conducted a trial in 2018 to ﬁnd out the rate of oxytocin infusion.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: All 150 women received 1 IU bolus of oxytocin followed by an oxytocin infusion at 0 1 3 5 8 IU/h.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: They found a 95% effective dose to be 7.72 IU/h and that the total oxytocin dose administered after delivery could be decreased if an infusion of oxytocin is given [22].

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: DiscussionProphylactic uterotonic agents can prevent PPH and are routinely recommended.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: A systematic Cochrane review on uterotonic agents which included 196 clinical trials (135 559 women) and was published in 2018 concluded that oxytocin is effective for preventing peripartum hemorrhage when compared with placebo or no treatment.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Er- gometrine plus oxytocin combination misoprostol plus oxytocin combination and car- betocin may have some additional desirable effects compared with oxytocin but the combination of two drugs is associated with more frequent side effects [23].

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: The main concern related to this topic is that there is not one opinion on what dosage of the uterotonic drug should be administered to prevent uterine atony and PPH.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Despite the fact that oxytocin is used in everyday obstetric practice it seems that it is used empirically.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: The guidelines present a wide variety of oxytocin bolus doses and different infusion dose and rate and are based on expert opinion mostly that means that recommendations are not strong.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: The current WHO recommendation published in 2018 for preventing PPH is 10 IU of intramuscular or intravenous oxytocin for the prevention of PPH for all births.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: That dose is not related to a high rate of side effects and it also can be divided into a smaller intravenous bolus and an infusion.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: A rapid intravenous bolus injection must be avoided.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: One of the important research priorities indicated by WHO is the identiﬁcation of the optimal regimen of intravenous oxytocin at caesarean section [24].

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: A study conducted in Canada in 2016–2017 showed that for both high- and low- risk CD participants doctors use 5 IU IV oxytocin bolus although the range differs from 3 to 10 IU.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: In addition to bolus they also use an infusion: 20 IU (range 20–40)/L for low-risk CD and 40 IU (range 20–60)/L for high-risk CD [25].

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: This study inspired the release of a newly updated guideline in Canada.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: However the same recommendation concerning CD remained as in the 2009 version stating that 100 µg of carbetocin should be given as an IV bolus over 1 min instead of continuous oxytocin infusion [26] The.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists also released updated recommendations for postpartum hemorrhage in 2017.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: But prevention of uterine atony was not discussed separately the closest recommendation was 10 IU of oxytocin bolus IV [27].

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: NATA consensus statements on prevention and treatment of postpartum hemorrhage were issued in 2019.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: They rec- ommended administering an adjusted 5–10 IU intravenous oxytocin dose as the preferred preventive treatment [28].

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: The Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists in the United Kingdom released updated recommendations for the prevention and management of postpartum hemorrhage in 2016.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: They recommend the same 5 IU oxytocin dose by slow IV injection [5].

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Guidelines released in France in 2015 stated that for prevention of postpartum hemorrhage after CD should be used 5–10 IU of oxytocin dose injected slowly (at least one-minute) IV [29].

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: It is very important to remember the fact that oxytocin is used for uterine atony prophylactics for most obstetric patients as supplementation of endogenous oxytocin.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Carvalho dose-ﬁnding study results revealed that bolus should be only 0.35 IU but it should be followed by oxytocin infusion [30].

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Balki and co-authors compared 30 women who were given 0.5 IU/mL IV oxytocin after the delivery.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: If the patient did not respond adequately to the initial bolus of oxytocin the initial dose for the next patient was increased by 0.5 IU.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: All patients received 20 IUInt.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Public Health 2021 18 5029 10 of 14oxytocin in 1 L saline.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: All patients who received 3.5 IU initial oxytocin dose showed adequate uterine response within 1–2 min.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: An important fact is that all parturients were given oxytocin before CD for a minimum of 2 h so the sensitivity of oxytocin receptors could be reduced.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: This study indicated that women undergoing CD for labor arrest require approximately 3 IU of oxytocin as a bolus to achieve adequate uterine contraction and continuous oxytocin infusion of 20 IU in 1 L saline after that [31].

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: These two studies revealed that an adequate dosage of oxytocin bolus can be as small as 3 IU or even less and an additional continuous infusion of oxytocin is needed.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: The previous oxytocin administration has no inﬂuence on the dose.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: A cross-sectional study carried out by Beiranvand et al.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: concluded that the minimum effective dose is 1 IU and in those in labor progress 1–1.5 IU both followed by 20 IU oxytocin in 1000 mL infusion [32].

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: The previously mentioned up-down sequential method study of Carvalho also resulted in a small minimum effective dose.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: We analyzed 5 studies investigating superior bolus dose.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: The four trials comparing constant continuous infusion of oxytocin and different bolus doses [10–13] two of them had the placebo group [10 13] found that smaller bolus dose or even no bolus dose has the same effect as the bigger one.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Sartain concluded that 2 IU is superior to 5 IU espe- cially if hemodynamics was analyzed [11].

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: In the study of Butwick more than a half of patients in the placebo group didn’t require a bolus dose [10] which is also conﬁrmed by King his study revealed that there is no difference in PPH between women who receive oxytocin bolus and those who do not [13].

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Jonsson conducted a trial without continuous infusion and also concluded that a smaller dose has lower incidence of cardiovascular side effects [14].

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: The cardiovascular effect of oxytocin is very important.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: It is detected that 10 IU oxytocin bolus may cause temporary hypotension and tachycardia as well as myocardial ischemia [33].

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Therefore when comparing the cardiovascular system response to oxytocin dosage a lower strategic tactic should be approached.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Both Cecilia Ghulmiyyah and partly King investigated the effect of oxytocin infusion without bolus dose.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: All of them found that the bolus of oxytocin is not necessary to achieve adequate and wanted uterine contraction and prevent PPH and the smaller dose of oxytocin (10–20) given as continuous infusion has the same effect as the bigger one [13 16 17].

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: This should also be taken into the consideration as previously discussed cardiovascular changes are observed almost in every patient given at least 5 IU bolus of oxytocin so the strategy of using only the infusion of oxytocin could be further researched or bolus dose should be as small as possible.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: The inclusion criteria met only one study investigating different bolus doses and continuous infusion of oxytocin.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Kovacheva found out that the clinical effect is similar but additional doses of oxytocin and side effects are lower in the bolus group.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: The results suggest that prophylactic bolus dose is sufﬁcient [15].

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: The possibility to avoid the infusion dose helps to reduce the total dose of oxytocin.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Dufﬁeld compared low and high doses of oxytocin given as a continuous infusion.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: That study conﬁrmed the previously mentioned result that both low (10 IU) and high (60 IU) infusion of oxytocin works in the same preventive regime [18].

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Although Dufﬁeld says that both high and low-dose infusions work in the same way receptor overstimulation should be taken into the consideration.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: It is known that clinical use of high-dose of oxytocin infusion longer than 3 to 4 h may diminish the response of uterus tonus to oxytocin [34].

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Robinson and colleagues in their study about oxytocin-induced desensitization of the oxytocin receptor concluded that oxytocin-induced desensitization of myocytes to oxytocin stimulation occurred over a clinically relevant time frame (4.2 h).

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Continued responsiveness of the cells to prostaglandin stimulation after 6 h of oxytocin pre-treatment indicated that post-receptor signaling pathways were maintained which indicates that the oxytocin receptor is likely involved in the mechanism of myocyte desensitization to oxytocin stimulation [34].

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Especially if as high as 60 IU doses of oxytocin were used to prevent PPH.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: High doses work in the same way as low ones doInt.

text: J.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Public Health 2021 18 5029 11 of 14because receptors cannot bind more hormone molecules to themselves meaning that there is no actual effect on uterine contraction after infusing oxytocin for too long and too much.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: We included ﬁve studies that had a very similar design.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: The bolus dose of oxytocin 5 IU was given and it was followed by infusion with placebo or oxytocin.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Oxytocin dose ranged between studies from 20 to 40 IU.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: The conclusion is that additional oxytocin infusion lowers the risk of PPH reduces the need for additional uterotonic agents and does not have a signiﬁcant impact on patients’ hemodynamic [19–23].

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: The discussion remains if and when the oxytocin given as an infusion is for prophylactic or for treatment of uterine atony because the infused oxytocin dose in mentioned studies is more appropriate for uterine atony treatment.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: The trials investigating the oxytocin effect on uterine tonus during CD have superiority over studies conducted in natural delivery because there is a possibility to evaluate real uterine tonus visually and by palpation and to ﬁnd out the smallest effective dose of the hormone.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: One more point for discussion is the duration of oxytocin infusion.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: It is different and ranges from one hour till 24 h between studies.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: We should take into account that a long-lasting infusion could reduce the sensitivity of oxytocin receptors as mentioned before and oxytocin could lose its power in the case of real uterine atony.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Further one more unanswered question is what duration of continuous infusion should be considered as prophylactic.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: It is known that clinical use of high-dose of oxytocin infusion longer than 3 to 4 h may diminish the response of uterus tonus to oxytocin [34].

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: The only study of Qian discusses prophylactic oxytocin infusion dose.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: They found a 95% effective dose to be 7.72 IU/h and that the total oxytocin dose administered after delivery can be decreased if the infusion of oxytocin is given [24].

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: The international consensus statement on the use of uterotonic agents during caesarean section was published in 2019.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Researchers from 8 different countries reached an agreement that oxytocin is the ﬁrst-line drug in both elective and intrapartum CD.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: For the ﬁrst one bolus of 1 IU oxytocin and infusion starting at 2.5–7.5 IU/h is recommended.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: For the latter 3 IU oxytocin bolus over ≥30 s and infusion starting at 7.5–15 IU/h was decided [35].

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Oxytocin given in very high doses change the mean level of arterial blood pressure in an opposing manner however under basal physiological conditions oxytocin does not contribute to blood pressure maintenance [36].

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: The hypotensive action of oxytocin demonstrated in animal models is believed to be mediated by the direct effect on oxytocin receptors in the heart and the indirect effect of the release of atrial natriuretic peptide brain natriuretic peptide and nitric oxide in the cardiovascular tissues [30].

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: This hormone has widely known cardiovascular side-effects mostly in decreasing blood pressure by causing peripheral vasodilation increasing the HR cases of myocardial ischemia and arrhythmias.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Thomas with his colleagues examined the effect of 5 IU bolus and 5 IU oxytocin infusion over 5 min.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Both heart rate and blood pressure were lower in the bolus group meaning that bolus should be injected slower than it is widely used [37].

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Langesaeter et al.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: with invasive monitoring (LiDCOPlus® monitor) in healthy preg- nant women observed an increase in cardiac index decreased systemic vascular resistance and systolic blood pressure (range of 36–62 mmHg) 45 s after oxytocin injection [38].

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: This same group of authors studied 18 patients with preeclampsia who underwent ce- sarean section.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: With the same monitoring as the previous study (LiDCOPlus®) connected to the radial artery of patients the authors found an increased heart rate and decreased systemic vascular resistance and blood pressure in all patients receiving oxytocin (5 IU) after delivery [39].

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: The hemodynamic instability that can occur during postpartum hemor- rhage may not be solely due to hypovolemia but the association of both hypovolemia and use of oxytocin bolus [40].

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: This review has several limitations.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: We could apply more strict inclusion criteria and include only randomized double-blind placebo controlled trials.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: The meta-analysis would provide more reliable results and conclusions it’s an option for future work.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Most studies mentioned the rate of bolus injection and it ranges from 5 s till 3 min [10–15 19–21 23 24].

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Further research investigating prophylactic bolus dose infusion rate isInt.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: J.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Environ.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Res.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Public Health 2021 18 5029 12 of 14necessary.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: It is possible that the slower bolus infusion rate could reduce the frequency of side effects or the request of additional doses of uterotonic drugs or even the necessity of oxytocin prophylactic infusion.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: ConclusionsOxytocin is the routinely used and effective uterotonic drug but the unanswered topic still remains the bolus dose size infusion dose size and requirement and bolus injection rate.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: The doses that are recommended in the guidelines of peripartum hemorrhage prophylaxis are not conﬁrmed by randomized controlled double-blind trials and are only supported by expert opinion and studies with low evidence rates.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Oxytocin bolus 0.5–3 UI is considered an effective prophylactic dose.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: The effective prophylactic oxytocin infusion dose is 7.72 I U/h.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: However it is unanswered whether this prophylactic infusion dose of oxytocin is required if an effective bolus dose size and rate are chosen.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: In the cases we use an oxytocin infusion we should separate if it is the prophylactic infusion or the treatment of atony.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: Adverse hemodynamic effects were observed when a 5 UI oxytocin bolus was used.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: This must be taken into consideration especially among female patients with any pre-existing heart conditions.

fname: Prophylactic Dose of Oxytocin
text: One of the important research priorities is the identiﬁcation of the optimal regiment of intravenous oxytocin at caesarean section.

Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: [CrossRef]Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage: A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis Holly B.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Ende MD M.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: James Lozada DO David H.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Chestnut MD Sarah S.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Osmundson  MD MS Rachel L.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Walden MLIS Matthew S.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Shotwell PhD Jeanette R.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Bauchat MD MS Departments of Anesthesiology Obstetrics and Gynecology and Biostatistics Vanderbilt University Medical Center and the Annette and Irwin Eskind Family Biomedical Library Vanderbilt University Nashville Tennessee.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Abstract OBJECTIVE: To identify and quantify risk factors for atonic postpartum hemorrhage.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: DATA SOURCES: PubMed CINAHL EMBASE Web of Science and and ClinicalTrials.gov databases were searched for English language studies with no restrictions on date or location.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Studies included randomized trials prospective or retrospective cohort studies and case–control studies of pregnant patients who developed atonic postpartum hemorrhage and reported at least one risk factor.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: METHODS OF STUDY SELECTION: Title abstract and full-text screening were performed using the Raayan web application.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Of 1 239 records screened 27 studies were included in this review.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Adjusted or unadjusted odds ratios (ORs) relative risks or rate ratios were recorded or calculated.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: For each risk factor a qualitative synthesis of low and moderate risk of bias studies classifies the risk factor as definite likely unclear or not a risk factor.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: For risk factors with sufficiently homogeneous definitions and reference ranges a quantitative meta-analysis of low and moderate risk of bias studies was implemented to estimate a combined OR.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: TABULATION INTEGRATION AND RESULTS: Forty-seven potential risk factors for atonic postpartum hemorrhage were identified in this review of which 15 were judged definite or likely risk factors.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: The remaining 32 assessed risk factors showed no association with atonic postpartum hemorrhage or had conflicting or unclear evidence.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: CONCLUSION: A substantial proportion of postpartum hemorrhage occurs in the absence of recognized risk factors.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Many risk factors for atonic hemorrhage included in current risk- assessment tools were confirmed with the greatest risk conferred by prior postpartum hemorrhage of any etiology placenta previa placental abruption uterine rupture and multiple gestation.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Novel risk factors not currently included in risk-assessment tools included hypertension diabetes and ethnicity.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Obesity and magnesium were not associated with atonic postpartum hemorrhage in this review.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Corresponding author: Holly B.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Ende Department of Anesthesiology Vanderbilt University Medical Center Nashville TN  holly.ende@vumc.org.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Each author has confirmed compliance with the journal’s requirements for authorship.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Financial Disclosure The authors did not report any potential conflicts of interest.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: HHS Public Access Author manuscript Obstet Gynecol.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Author manuscript available in PMC 2021 August 04.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Published in final edited form as: Obstet Gynecol.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage

Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Author Manuscript Author Manuscript Author Manuscript Author Manuscript SYSTEMATIC REVIEW REGISTRATION: PROSPERO CRD42020157521.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Postpartum hemorrhage affects 3–10% of deliveries and accounts for nearly 20% of maternal deaths worldwide.1 2 Although there are many etiologies uterine atony is the most common and accounts for nearly 70% of cases.3 Patients who experience postpartum hemorrhage can have increased morbidity and mortality which can be attenuated by identifying patients at risk early preparation and increased vigilance.1 4 Risk stratification for postpartum hemorrhage is commonly performed using an assessment tool from one of several organizations such as the California Maternal Quality Care Collaborative  Association of Women’s Health Obstetric and Neonatal Nurses or the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists.5–7 Although these risk-assessment tools have the support of major medical societies recent evidence suggests that the tools have only moderate predictive value for severe hemorrhage in the highest risk groups and that a significant portion of hemorrhages (up to 43%) occur in those deemed low risk.8 9 This limitation may be partly due to the tools’ development via expert consensus opinion and a lack of systematically reviewed evidence to support or refute the included risk factors.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: A recently published meta-analysis that evaluated the association between maternal demographics and comorbidities and postpartum hemorrhage evaluated only four potential risk factors and found body mass index nulliparity and hypertensive disorders to confer risk of postpartum hemorrhage.11 Additionally existing tools assess the risk of all postpartum hemorrhage etiologies simultaneously which may confound attempts at risk prediction because each etiology of postpartum hemorrhage is likely associated with different risk factors.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Furthermore current tools fail to account for the relative contribution of each risk factor or to provide mechanisms to quantify risk for a given patient when more than one risk factor is present.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Because each etiology of postpartum hemorrhage likely has a unique set of risk factors evaluating each etiology separately may improve the ability to delineate individual patient risk.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: The systematic identification and quantification of risk factors for atonic postpartum hemorrhage may allow the development of more reliable weighted risk- stratification tools.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Thus this systematic review aimed to identify risk factors that increase the odds of a patient developing postpartum hemorrhage due only to uterine atony after vaginal or cesarean delivery.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: SOURCES This review follows the PRISMA (Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-analyses) statement11 and was registered with the PROSPERO International Prospective Register for Systematic Reviews (registration number CRD42020157521).

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: The PubMed (National Library of Medicine) CI-NAHL (EBSCO) EMBASE (Ovid) Web of Science (Clarivate) and ClinicalTrials.gov (National Institutes of Health) databases were searched in November 2018 for English language studies with no restrictions on date or geographic location.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: PubMed MeSH headings included but were not limited to postpartum hemorrhage uterine hemorrhage uterine inertia causality epidemiology incidence  methylergonovine misoprostol oxytocin prevalence probability risk assessment risk factors and risk in addition to corresponding keywords (full search strategies are shown inEnde et al.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Page 2Obstet Gynecol.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Author manuscript available in PMC 2021 August 04.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Author Manuscript Author Manuscript Author Manuscript Author Manuscript The PubMed search was translated for CINAHL EMBASE Web of Science and clinicaltrials.gov.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: STUDY SELECTION Eligibility for inclusion was limited to randomized clinical trials prospective or retrospective cohort studies and case–control studies written in the English language with pregnant patients who developed postpartum uterine atony or atonic postpartum hemorrhage.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Definitions of atonic postpartum hemorrhage varied by study and included some combination of clinical diagnoses second-line uterotonic administration estimated blood loss need for transfusion or International Classification of Diseases codes (Table 1).

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Studies were excluded if they reported postpartum hemorrhage data without specifying etiology or if they did not report the incidence of at least one risk factor for postpartum hemorrhage in a uterine atony subgroup.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Case reports case series and unpublished meeting abstracts were excluded.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Two blinded authors screened abstracts and a third blinded author resolved conflicts.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Full-text articles were obtained for all included abstracts.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Full-text article review was conducted by the same two blinded authors with conflicts resolved in the same manner.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Title abstract and full-text screening were performed using the Raayan web application.12The risk of bias for each included study was assessed using the Risk of Bias Assessment Tool for Nonrandomized Studies.13 This tool was chosen because of the nonrandomized nature of all included studies as well as its scope in assessing multiple sources of bias  including those related to selection performance detection attrition and reporting.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Six domains of risk of bias were assessed including: 1) selection of participants 2) confounding variables 3) measurement of exposure 4) blinding of outcome assessments 5) incomplete outcome data and 6) selective outcome reporting.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Bias scoring proceeded after training each scorer on the assessment tool to ensure good inter-rater reliability correlation.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Two authors (D.H.C.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: H.B.E.) independently assessed the risk of bias for each study with disagreements resolved by a third blinded author (J.R.B.).

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Studies were found to have a low risk of bias if they attained a low-risk classification in all six evaluated domains.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Studies were considered a moderate risk of bias if at least one domain was rated unclear risk (but no domains were rated high risk).

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Finally studies were found to have a high risk of bias if at least one domain was rated high risk.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: All data were collected independently by co-investigators into a study spreadsheet and verified by a separate author.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: In addition to baseline study characteristics including country of origin study design the number of patients and inclusion and exclusion criteria data were collected on all risk factors for atonic postpartum hemorrhage reported in the study.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: For each risk factor adjusted or unadjusted odds ratios (aOR uOR) relative risks (aRR  uRR) or rate ratios (arr urr) were recorded when available.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: If not explicitly reported uOR and 95% CI were calculated with a 2×2 table using the number of patients with and without a given risk factor who developed atonic postpartum hemorrhage.14 The primary outcome assessed in all studies was the OR RR or rr of risk factors associated with atonic postpartum hemorrhage.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: For each identified risk factor low and moderate risk of bias studies were synthesized qualitatively to label each risk factor as definite likely unclear or not a risk factor based on the number of total studies evaluating the factor and percentage ofEnde et al.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Page 3Obstet Gynecol.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Author manuscript available in PMC 2021 August 04.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Author Manuscript Author Manuscript Author Manuscript Author Manuscript studies showing a positive association (Box 1).

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: For risk factors with sufficiently homogeneous definitions and reference ranges a quantitative meta-analysis of low and moderate risk of bias studies was implemented to estimate a combined OR.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: The inverse variance random effects method was used for meta-analysis.15 This method requires only effect estimates (ie OR or risk ratios) and their SEs.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: The SEs were estimated by backtransforming the 95% confidence limits using the standard normal distribution.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: The DerSimonian-Laird estimator was used to estimate the between-study variance in effects.16Owing to the rarity of uterine atony (and thus the near-equivalence of the OR and RR)  studies that reported a risk ratio were included.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Adjusted and unadjusted risk ratios and ORs were included.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: The I2 statistic and a P-value against the null hypothesis (ie I250) are reported for each subgroup.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: The I2 statistic represents the percentage of variability in the effect estimates that is attributable to study heterogeneity (compared with sampling heterogeneity).

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: RESULTS The database search revealed 1 977 total records and 1 239 records were screened after removing duplicates.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: After excluding 871 records based on title and abstract review 368 full-text articles were assessed for eligibility (Fig.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Twenty-seven studies reported data for at least one risk factor for atonic postpartum hemorrhage and were included in the narrative summary.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Of those 19 studies contributed data to the qualitative synthesis and 13 to the meta-analysis.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Table 1 summarizes the study design patient population study definitions of postpartum hemorrhage and uterine atony and the risk factors assessed in the included studies.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: The scoring for risk of bias for each study is reported in Figure 2.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: A total of 47 unique risk factors were identified in the search: 15 relating to maternal history or demographics 11 to maternal comorbidities six pregnancy-related factors eight labor- related factors and seven delivery-related factors.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: For qualitative comparison the authors characterized each risk factor as definite likely unclear or not a risk factor based on the number of low and moderate risk of bias studies that showed statistically significant evidence that the risk factor was associated with atony (Box 1).

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Six variables were found to be definite risk factors for atonic postpartum hemorrhage based on either all low and moderate risk of bias studies showing a positive association (if at least three studies) or the majority of low and moderate risk of bias studies showing a positive association (if at least five studies).

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: An additional nine variables were deemed likely associated with atonic postpartum hemorrhage  and these included being of Hispanic ethnicity nulliparity hypertensive diseases of pregnancy multiple gestation chorioamnionitis uterine rupture predelivery oxytocin exposure induction of labor and instrumented vaginal delivery.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Some variables that areEnde et al.
