text: Author Manuscript Author Manuscript Author Manuscript Author Manuscript traditionally considered risk factors for postpartum hemorrhage were not found to be associated specifically with atonic postpartum hemorrhage in this review but may confer risk for hemorrhage due to other etiologies.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: These included maternal obesity leiomyomas  polyhydramnios prolonged second stage of labor magnesium exposure and cesarean delivery.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Meta-analysis was implemented for 24 risk factors with at least two low or moderate risk of bias studies demonstrating homogeneous risk factor definitions and reference ranges (Figs.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Table 2 displays a summary of qualitative and quantitative (where applicable) results for each risk factor.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: DISCUSSION This systematic review highlights several previously unrecognized risk factors for atonic postpartum hemorrhage that are not included in current risk-assessment tools and it questions whether other risk factors used in current tools are in fact supported by published evidence.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: This review also provides further evidence supporting the validity of many risk factors already included in risk-stratification tools and provides quantitative estimates of their contribution to atonic postpartum hemorrhage risk.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Although some risk factors presented may cause postpartum hemorrhage independently for example genital tract trauma or abnormal placentation these factors also appear to contribute to uterine atony  and thus are captured in this review.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Perhaps most importantly current risk-assessment tools fail to include some definite or likely risk factors that appear to be well-established in the literature.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Hispanic ethnicity (OR 1.23 95% CI 1.20–1.25) and Asian race (OR 1.39 95% 1.33–1.46) were associated with atonic postpartum hemorrhage in this review and are missing from current risk-assessment tools.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: The ORs for ethnicity and race are comparable with those for commonly cited risk factors including induction of labor (OR 1.23 95% 1.10–1.39) and macrosomia (OR 1.46  95% 1.35–1.57).

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Given the mounting evidence of disparities in the care of minority women  we may be failing to anticipate the increased risk of postpartum hemorrhage in these populations.17 These associations do not imply causation and it is unclear whether the underlying mechanism of these relationships are biological social or a byproduct of disparities or systematic racism.18 Specific attention must be paid when including race or ethnicity in risk-prediction systems because recent evidence suggests that these algorithms may perpetuate health care disparities.19 20Hypertensive disease (OR 1.84 95% 1.45–2.33) and diabetes mellitus (OR 1.22 95% 1.08– 1.39) both of which are known to be associated with vascular and perfusion abnormalities  also emerged as previously underappreciated risk factors for atonic postpartum hemorrhage.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: 21–23 We hypothesize that the vascular pathophysiology of these diseases may contributeEnde et al.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Page 5Obstet Gynecol.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Author manuscript available in PMC 2021 August 04.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Author Manuscript Author Manuscript Author Manuscript Author Manuscript directly to the development of atony and hemorrhage however genetic susceptibility to both atony and hypertension or diabetes in specific patient populations may also explain this association and certainly warrants further investigation.24 25 Interestingly high vaginal lacerations and cervical trauma are not included in current risk-assessment tools.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: However  high vaginal and cervical lacerations demonstrated higher OR than either instrumented delivery or perineal trauma both of which are included in the Association of Women’s Health Obstetric and Neonatal Nurses’ risk-stratification tool.6 Although nulliparity and prolonged first stage of labor were found to be associated with atonic postpartum hemorrhage and are not included in the current risk-assessment tools they may be associated with other risk factors that are included such as induction of labor oxytocin use and chorioamnionitis.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Of these factors chorioamnionitis demonstrated the highest OR of 1.93 (95% CI 1.56–2.39) and may contribute significantly to an increased risk associated with nulliparity or prolonged first stage of labor.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Finally uterine rupture was found to be associated with atonic postpartum hemorrhage.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Although not specifically described in the studies that reported this association hemorrhage attributable to uterine atony presumably occurred after repair of the uterine defect.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Additionally some risk factors currently included in risk-assessment tools are not supported by this literature review of atonic postpartum hemorrhage although an association with other etiologies of postpartum hemorrhage would not be captured by this study.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Prolonged second stage of labor (which is included in nearly all risk-assessment tools) did not emerge as a definite risk factor for atonic postpartum hemorrhage in our systematic review and meta-analysis with combined OR 1.10 (95% CI 0.82–1.48).

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Polyhydramnios did not emerge as a risk factor for atonic postpartum hemorrhage in quantitative analysis with combined OR 1.29 (95% CI 0.94–1.76) despite the historical identification of polyhydramnios as a cause of atonic postpartum hemorrhage due to uterine overdistention.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Macrosomia and multiple gestation which are implicated by a similar mechanism did demonstrate increased risk with combined OR of 1.46 (95% CI 1.35–1.57) and 2.16 (95% CI 1.53–3.06)  respectively.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Uterine overdistention alone however may not fully explain the variability in the risk of atony that is observed between these three conditions.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: For example multiple gestation pregnancies are frequently due to in vitro fertilization which has been associated with increased risk of postpartum hemorrhage possibly due to abnormalities of placental implantation and endometrial function.26 Additionally there may be some underlying immunologic vascular or genetic pathophysiology that overlaps with infertility and atonic postpartum hemorrhage.27–30Obesity and magnesium exposure are additional factors included in most risk-assessment tools however neither showed associations with atonic postpartum hemorrhage in this review.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: It is possible that the underlying conditions (ie diabetes mellitus hypertension) are the real risk factors as discussed above leaving the clinical impression that obesity and magnesium increase postpartum hemorrhage risk and leading some studies to find a positive effect.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Given the retrospective nature of most included studies however magnesium exposure and dosing may have been inadequately captured hindering the ability to demonstrate an association with atonic postpartum hemorrhage.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Ende et al.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Page 6Obstet Gynecol.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Author manuscript available in PMC 2021 August 04.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Author Manuscript Author Manuscript Author Manuscript Author Manuscript Cesarean delivery and uterine leiomyomas are included in the risk-assessment tools but were not found to be associated with atonic postpartum hemorrhage by either qualitative or quantitative analysis.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Because intrapartum cesarean delivery is associated with factors (eg  prolonged labor and oxytocin exposure) shown to increase the risk of atonic postpartum hemorrhage this may contribute to a positive association in studies or a clinical impression that cesarean delivery is significantly associated with atonic postpartum hemorrhage.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: The occurrence of leiomyomas varies significantly in size location vascularity and previous surgical interventions which may influence the ability to determine the significance of leiomyomas as a risk factor in published studies.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Finally many risk factors already included in widely adopted risk-assessment tools are further confirmed in this systematic review as associated with atonic postpartum hemorrhage —prior postpartum hemorrhage multiple gestation placental disorders (previa or abruption) chorioamnionitis predelivery oxytocin exposure induction of labor prolonged labor perineal trauma and instrumented vaginal delivery.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Although some of these factors (eg abnormal placentation birth canal trauma) are etiologies for postpartum hemorrhage themselves the evidence presented here suggests that they are additionally associated with the development of uterine atony.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: This evidence further supports the inclusion of these factors when stratifying risk and our data may help health care professionals improve tools by assigning a quantitative weight to risk factors with a stronger association with atonic postpartum hemorrhage.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Additionally current tools likely can be further improved by more nuanced definitions of some factors shown to have a robust association with atonic postpartum hemorrhage.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: For example further delineation of genital tract trauma may be warranted although episiotomy or perineal tear (OR 1.67 95% 1.28–2.18) is included in some current risk-assessment tools high vaginal laceration and cervical laceration are not (OR 2.19 95% 1.13–4.24 and 5.70 95% 2.56–12.67 respectively).

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: The data for oxytocin exposure which also are already included in current risk-assessment tools presented the most significant challenge in the interpretation of results for this systematic review.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Although qualitative synthesis suggested an association between predelivery oxytocin exposure and atonic postpartum hemorrhage the meta-analysis failed to confirm the association (combined OR 1.15 95% 0.95–1.40).

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Importantly two low risk of bias studies were not included in the meta-analysis because of heterogeneity in defining the exposure and reference ranges (eg evaluating oxytocin per unit dose).

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: With conflicting results it is essential also to consider the mechanism by which oxytocin likely contributes to atonic postpartum hemorrhage namely that tachyphylaxis to oxytocin occurs during labor  thereby decreasing efficacy of the primary drug used for the active management the third stage of labor.31–33 Further investigation is needed to determine the cut-offs for the amount or duration of oxytocin that leads to an increased risk of atony.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Although the risk-assessment tools may be refined by adding keeping or removing risk factors the individual weights and whether each individually or in combination defines an individual patient’s postpartum hemorrhage risk as moderate or high remains undetermined.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: When preparing and allocating resources for potential postpartum hemorrhage the use of risk scores that weigh the variable contribution of risk factors may be preferable to the use of tools that merely collate a list of diagnoses with many associated or overlapping risk factors.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Ende et al.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Page 7Obstet Gynecol.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Author manuscript available in PMC 2021 August 04.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Author Manuscript Author Manuscript Author Manuscript Author Manuscript To this end recent headway has been made in using statistical modeling and machine learning to predict postpartum hemorrhage.34 Notably however a substantial proportion of postpartum hemorrhage occurs in the absence of recognized risk factors.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: The strengths of this systematic review include the systematic approach to identifying all publications that included risk factors for atonic postpartum hemorrhage and the division of risk factors into maternal pregnancy-related labor-related and delivery-related conditions to provide a logical progression of possible etiologies of atonic postpartum hemorrhage.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Finally we evaluated each variable both qualitatively and quantitatively to summarize a large number of studies in a comprehensive review.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: The results of this systematic review and meta-analysis however must be considered in the context of several limitations.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: First we had to accept the authors’ definitions of atonic postpartum hemorrhage which varied from study to study.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: The most common definitions in large database studies were rather consistent using International Classification of Diseases codes for postpartum hemorrhage due to atony.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: The variability occurred primarily in the smaller studies which used definitions of postpartum hemorrhage that included estimated blood loss postpartum hemoglobin or hematocrit drop and clinical diagnosis with additional definitions for the diagnosis of atony including uterotonic administration medical team diagnosis or other surgical interventions.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: These definitions represent a spectrum of pathology and each study’s definition may have affected the magnitude of associations of any given risk factor.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Second  because all authors were fluent only in English we restricted our search to English-language studies which contributed to publication bias.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Third for thoroughness we did include in the narrative summary studies with a high risk of bias however we included only studies with a low or moderate risk of bias when evaluating each risk factor both qualitatively and quantitatively.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Fourth the types of effect estimates reported and the factors used to adjust for potential confounding were heterogeneous across studies.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Additionally nearly all reported ORs and RRs reflect weak associations (range 1–2) which are likely below the discriminatory ability of the included cohort and case–control studies.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: These observations may result from unmeasured bias or confounding.35 Lastly to summarize risk factors qualitatively we had to provide a unique definition to categorize a risk factor as definite  likely or unclear.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Although these definitions were created de novo for this review a post hoc evaluation revealed that for those variables designated definite risk factors all (six of six) showed statistically significant combined OR.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Of the variables designated likely eight of nine were amenable to meta-analysis and seven showed statistically significant increased odds of atonic postpartum hemorrhage.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Finally 15 variables were classified as unclear risk factors with only six of those demonstrating data homogeneous enough for meta-analysis  and of those only one (macrosomia) demonstrated a statistically significant OR.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: In summary this systematic review and meta-analysis of risk factors for postpartum hemorrhage due to uterine atony provides critical insights to help guide future obstetric care.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: By more narrowly defining our focus to only atonic postpartum hemorrhage we aimed to provide more definitive evidence supporting or refuting presumed risk factors given that each etiology of postpartum hemorrhage likely has a unique set of contributing factors.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: These findings should lead researchers and clinicians to refine current risk-assessment tools further.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Future tools should include weighted values for risk factors or modeling risk levelsEnde et al.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Page 8Obstet Gynecol.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Author manuscript available in PMC 2021 August 04.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Author Manuscript Author Manuscript Author Manuscript Author Manuscript by the etiology of postpartum hemorrhage.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Finally the genetic basis for postpartum hemorrhage warrants further investigation and eventual inclusion into risk-assessment tools.

text: Defining the Strength of a Risk Factor Definite All low and moderate risk of bias studies positive (at least three studies) Majority (more than 50%) low and moderate risk of bias studies positive (at least five studies) Likely All low and moderate risk of bias studies positive (two studies) Majority (more than 50%) low and moderate risk of bias studies positive (2–4 studies) Unclear All low and moderate risk of bias studies positive (one study) Low and moderate risk of bias studies show mixed or conflicting results A majority (more than 50%) of studies negative but at least one low or moderate risk of bias study positive Not a risk factor No low or moderate risk of bias studies positive Ende et al.

text: Risk of bias assessment.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Risk of bias assessments were performed using the Risk of Bias Assessment Tool for Nonrandomized Studies.13 Green (+) indicates low risk of bias blue (?) indicates unclear risk of bias and red (X) indicates high risk of bias.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: For the summary of risk of bias studies were considered overall low risk of bias (green +) if they were classified as low risk in all six domains.

fname: Risk Factors for Atonic Postpartum Hemorrhage
text: Studies were considered a moderate risk of bias (yellow —) if at least one domain was rated unclear risk (but no domains were rated high risk) and high risk (red X) if at least one domain was rated high risk.

text: A.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Metin Gülmezo- glu Matthews Mathai and Edgardo Abalos commented on the draft document before it was reviewed by Natasha Hezelgrave and participants at the WHO Technical Consultation on the Prevention and Treatment of PPH (see Annex 1).

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: We acknowledge gratefully the valuable feedback given by a large number of international stakeholders during the online consultation which took place as part of this process.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage 2 Abbreviations AGREE Appraisal of Guidelines Research and Evaluation AMTSL Active Management of the Third Stage of Labour CCT Controlled Cord Traction CI Confidence Interval GREAT Guideline development Research priorities Evidence synthesis    Applicability of evidence Transfer of knowledge (a WHO project) GDG Guideline Development Group GRADE Grading of Recommendations Assessment Development and Evaluation HIV Human immunodeficiency virus IM Intramuscular IU International Unit IV Intravenous MCA Maternal Child and Adolescent Department µg Microgram MMR Maternal Mortality Ratio PICO Population Interventions Comparisons and Outcomes PO Per Os (orally) PPH Postpartum Haemorrhage RCT Randomized Controlled Trial RevMan Review Manager (software) RR Relative Risk OR Odds Ratio USAID United States Agency for International Development WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage 3 Executive summary Introduction Postpartum Haemorrhage (PPH) is commonly defined as a blood loss of 500 ml or more within 24 hours after birth.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: PPH is the leading cause of maternal mortality in low-income countries and the primary cause of nearly one quarter of all maternal deaths globally.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Most deaths resulting from PPH occur during the first 24 hours after birth: the majority of these could be avoided through the use of prophylactic utero- tonics during the third stage of labour and by timely and appropriate management.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Improving health care for women during childbirth in order to prevent and treat PPH is an essential step towards the achievement of the Millennium Development Goals.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The primary objective of this guideline therefore is to provide a foundation for the strategic policy and programme development needed to ensure the sustainable implementation of effective interventions for reducing the global burden of PPH.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Guideline development methods The procedures used in the development of this guideline are outlined in the “WHO handbook for guideline development”1.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Briefly these procedures are: (i) the identi- fication of questions related to clinical practice and health policy for which answers are needed (ii) the retrieval of up-to-date research-based evidence (iii) the as- sessment and synthesis of evidence (iv) the formulation of recommendations using input from a wide range of stakeholders and (v) the formulation of plans for the dissemination implementation impact evaluation and updating of the guideline.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The scientific evidence for the recommendations was synthesized using the Grading of Recommendations Assessment Development and Evaluation (GRADE) methodol- ogy.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: For each of the previous WHO recommendations on PPH (2007 and 2009) and for all the newly-added questions evidence profiles were prepared based on 22 up-to-date systematic reviews.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The revised and new recommendations were devel- oped and adopted by an international group of experts who participated in the WHO Technical Consultation on the Prevention and Treatment of PPH held in Montreux  Switzerland 6–8 March 2012.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The WHO Technical Consultation adopted 32 recommendations and these are shown in Boxes A B and C.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: For each recommendation the quality of the supporting evi- dence is graded as ‘very low’ ‘low’ ‘moderate’ or ‘high’.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The contributing stake- holders qualified the strength of these recommendations by taking the quality of the evidence and other factors into account (including the values and preferences of stakeholders the magnitude of effect the balance of benefits versus disadvantages  resource usage and the feasibility of each recommendation).

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: To ensure that each recommendation is correctly understood and used in practice additional remarks have also been included and these are noted in the full document below the recom- mendations.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Readers should refer to these remarks in the full version of the guide- line if they are in any doubt about the meaning of each recommendation.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: 1 WHO handbook for guideline development.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Geneva World Health Organization 2012.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage 4 Recommendations for PPH prevention The intrinsic contribution of each component of the ‘active management of the third stage of labour’ was examined in light of new available evidence and relevant recommendations were made.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: All women giving birth should be offered uterotonics during the third stage of labour for the prevention of PPH oxytocin (IM/IV 10 IU) is recommended as the uterotonic drug of choice.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Other injectable uterotonics and misoprostol are recommended as alternatives for the prevention of PPH in settings where oxytocin is unavailable.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The importance of controlled cord traction (CCT) was revisited because of new evidence.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: This intervention is now regarded as optional in settings where skilled birth attendants are available and is contraindicated in settings where skilled attendants do not assist with births.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Early cord clamping is generally contraindicated.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Continuous uterine massage is not recommended as an intervention to prevent PPH in women who have received prophylactic oxytocin  as it may cause maternal discomfort require a dedicated health professional and may not lead to a reduction of blood loss.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: However surveillance of uterine tonus through abdominal palpation is recommended in all women for early identification of postpartum uterine atony.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: In summary the Guideline Development Group (GDG) considered the use of uterotonics as the main intervention within the active man- agement of third stage of labour package.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: In this context the use of misoprostol for the prevention of PPH by community health care workers and lay health workers is supported in settings where skilled birth attendants are not present.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The GDG also issued recommendations for reducing blood loss during the third stage of labour in caesarean sections.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Oxytocin is the recommended uterotonic drug for the prevention of PPH in caesarean sections.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Cord traction is recommended in pref- erence to manual removal when assisting placental delivery in caesarean sections.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Recommendations for PPH treatment The use of uterotonics (oxytocin alone as the first choice) plays a central role in the treatment of PPH.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Uterine massage is recommended for the treatment of PPH as soon as it is diagnosed and initial fluid resuscitation with isotonic crystalloids is recommended.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The use of tranexamic acid is advised in cases of refractory atonic bleeding or persistent trauma-related bleeding.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The use of intrauterine balloon tamponade is recommended for refractory bleeding or if uterotonics are unavail- able.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Bimanual uterine compression external aortic compression and the use of non-pneumatic anti-shock garments are recommended as temporizing measures until substantive care is available.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: If there is persistent bleeding and the relevant re- sources are available uterine artery embolization should be considered.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: If bleeding persists despite treatment with uterotonic drugs and other conservative interven- tions surgical intervention should be used without further delay.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: If the third stage of labour lasts more than 30 minutes CCT and IV/IM oxytocin (10 IU) should be used to manage the retained placenta.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: If the placenta is retained and bleeding occurs the manual removal of the placenta should be expedited.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Whenever the manual removal of the placenta is undertaken a single dose of pro- phylactic antibiotics is recommended.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The GDG also issued recommendations related to the organization of PPH care.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Health facilities delivering maternity services should adopt formal protocols for the prevention and treatment of PPH and for patient referral.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The use of PPH treatmentWHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage 5 simulations for pre-service and in-service training programmes was recommended.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Finally the GDG recommended that the use of uterotonics for the prevention of PPH should be monitored and a specific indicator was suggested.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Box A: Recommendations for the prevention of PPH 1.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The use of uterotonics for the prevention of PPH during the third stage of labour is recom-mended for all births.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Strong recommendation moderate-quality evidence)2.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Oxytocin (10 IU IV/IM) is the recommended uterotonic drug for the prevention of PPH.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Strong recommendation moderate-quality evidence) 3.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: In settings where oxytocin is unavailable the use of other injectable uterotonics (if appro-priate ergometrine/methylergometrine or the fixed drug combination of oxytocin and ergo- metrine) or oral misoprostol (600 µg) is recommended.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Strong recommendation moderate- quality evidence)4.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: In settings where skilled birth attendants are not present and oxytocin is unavailable theadministration of misoprostol (600 µg PO) by community health care workers and lay health workers is recommended for the prevention of PPH.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Strong recommendation moderate- quality evidence)5.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: In settings where skilled birth attendants are available CCT is recommended for vaginalbirths if the care provider and the parturient woman regard a small reduction in blood loss and a small reduction in the duration of the third stage of labour as important (Weak recom- mendation high-quality evidence) 6.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: In settings where skilled birth attendants are unavailable CCT is not recommended.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Strongrecommendation moderate-quality evidence) 7.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Late cord clamping (performed after 1 to 3 minutes after birth) is recommended for all birthswhile initiating simultaneous essential newborn care.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Strong recommendation moderate- quality evidence)8.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Early cord clamping (<1 minute after birth) is not recommended unless the neonate is as-phyxiated and needs to be moved immediately for resuscitation.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Strong recommendation  moderate-quality evidence)9.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Sustained uterine massage is not recommended as an intervention to prevent PPH in womenwho have received prophylactic oxytocin.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Weak recommendation low-quality evidence)10.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Postpartum abdominal uterine tonus assessment for early identification of uterine atony isrecommended for all women.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Strong recommendation very-low-quality evidence)11.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Oxytocin (IV or IM) is the recommended uterotonic drug for the prevention of PPH in caesar-ean section.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Strong recommendation moderate-quality evidence)12.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Controlled cord traction is the recommended method for removal of the placenta in caesar-ean section.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Strong recommendation moderate-quality evidence)WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage 6 Box B: Recommendations for the treatment of PPH 13.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Intravenous oxytocin alone is the recommended uterotonic drug for the treatment of PPH.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Strong recommendation moderate-quality evidence) 14.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: If intravenous oxytocin is unavailable or if the bleeding does not respond to oxytocin the useof intravenous ergometrine oxytocin-ergometrine fixed dose or a prostaglandin drug (includ- ing sublingual misoprostol 800 µg) is recommended.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Strong recommendation low-quality evidence)15.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The use of isotonic crystalloids is recommended in preference to the use of colloids for theinitial intravenous fluid resuscitation of women with PPH.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Strong recommendation low-qual- ity evidence)16.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The use of tranexamic acid is recommended for the treatment of PPH if oxytocin and otheruterotonics fail to stop bleeding or if it is thought that the bleeding may be partly due to trauma.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Weak recommendation moderate-quality evidence)17.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Uterine massage is recommended for the treatment of PPH.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Strong recommendation very-low-quality evidence) 18.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: If women do not respond to treatment using uterotonics or if uterotonics are unavailablethe use of intrauterine balloon tamponade is recommended for the treatment of PPH due to uterine atony.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Weak recommendation very-low-quality evidence)19.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: If other measures have failed and if the necessary resources are available the use of uter-ine artery embolization is recommended as a treatment for PPH due to uterine atony.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Weak recommendation very-low-quality evidence)20.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: If bleeding does not stop in spite of treatment using uterotonics and other available conserva-tive interventions (e.g.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: uterine massage balloon tamponade) the use of surgical interven- tions is recommended.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Strong recommendation very-low-quality evidence)21.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The use of bimanual uterine compression is recommended as a temporizing measure until ap-propriate care is available for the treatment of PPH due to uterine atony after vaginal deliv- ery.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Weak recommendation very-low-quality evidence)22.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The use of external aortic compression for the treatment of PPH due to uterine atony aftervaginal birth is recommended as a temporizing measure until appropriate care is available.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Weak recommendation very-low-quality evidence)23.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The use of non-pneumatic anti-shock garments is recommended as a temporizing measureuntil appropriate care is available.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Weak recommendation low-quality evidence)24.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The use of uterine packing is not recommended for the treatment of PPH due to uterine atonyafter vaginal birth.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Weak recommendation very-low-quality evidence)25.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: If the placenta is not expelled spontaneously the use of IV/IM oxytocin (10 IU) in combina-tion with controlled cord traction is recommended.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Weak recommendation very-low-quality evidence)26.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The use of ergometrine for the management of retained placenta is not recommended as thismay cause tetanic uterine contractions which may delay the expulsion of the placenta.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Weak recommendation very-low-quality evidence)27.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The use of prostaglandin E2 alpha (dinoprostone or sulprostone) for the management of re-tained placenta is not recommended.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Weak recommendation very-low-quality evidence)28.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: A single dose of antibiotics (ampicillin or first-generation cephalosporin) is recommended ifmanual removal of the placenta is practised.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Weak recommendation very-low-quality evi- dence)WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage 7 Box C: Organization of care 29.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The use of formal protocols by health facilities for the prevention and treatment of PPH isrecommended.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Weak recommendation moderate-quality evidence)30.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The use of formal protocols for referral of women to a higher level of care is recommendedfor health facilities.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Weak recommendation very-low-quality evidence)31.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The use of simulations of PPH treatment is recommended for pre-service and in-service train-ing programmes.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Weak recommendation very-low-quality evidence)32.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Monitoring the use of uterotonics after birth for the prevention of PPH is recommended asa process indicator for programmatic evaluation.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Weak recommendation very-low-quality evidence)WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage 8 1.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: BackgroundPostpartum Haemorrhage (PPH) is commonly defined as a blood loss of 500 ml or more within 24 hours after birth while severe PPH is defined as a blood loss of 1000 ml or more within the same timeframe.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: PPH affects approximately 2% of all women who give birth: it is associated not only with nearly one quarter of all ma- ternal deaths globally but is also the leading cause of maternal mortality in most low-income countries.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: PPH is a significant contributor to severe maternal morbidity and long-term disability as well as to a number of other severe maternal conditions generally associated with more substantial blood loss including shock and organ dys- function.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (1–3)Uterine atony is the most common cause of PPH but genital tract trauma (i.e.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: vagi- nal or cervical lacerations) uterine rupture retained placental tissue or maternal coagulation disorders may also result in PPH.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Although the majority of women who experience PPH complications have no identifiable clinical or historical risk factors  grand multiparity and multiple gestation are associated with an increased risk of bleeding after birth.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: PPH may be aggravated by pre-existing anaemia and in such instances the loss of a smaller volume of blood may still result in adverse clinical sequelae.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (4)During the second half of the 20th century a package of interventions performed during the third stage of labour became the cornerstone for the prevention of PPH.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: This approach became known as the “active management of the third stage of labour” and consisted initially of the following components: the administration of a prophylactic uterotonic after the delivery of a baby early cord clamping and cutting and the controlled traction of the umbilical cord.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Uterine massage is also frequently included as part of the active management of the third stage of labour.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: In contrast to active management expectant management involves instead waiting for signs of placenta separation and allows for the placenta to be delivered sponta- neously or aided by nipple stimulation or gravity.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Compared with expectant man- agement the active management of the third stage of labour is associated with a substantial reduction in the occurrence of PPH.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (5)It is generally assumed that by preventing and treating PPH most PPH-associated deaths could be avoided.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The prevention and treatment of PPH are therefore vital steps towards improving the health care of women during childbirth and the achievement of the Millennium Development Goals.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: To reach these objectives  health workers in developing countries should be given access to appropriate medi- cations and be trained in procedures relevant to the management of PPH.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Countries also need evidence-based guidance to inform their health policies and improve their health outcomes.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Given the availability of new scientific evidence related to the prevention and treat- ment of PPH the aim of this document is to revise previous WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of PPH and to add new recommendations.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The primary goal of this guideline is to provide a foundation for the implementation of strategic policy and programme developments for interventions shown to have been effective in reducing the burden of PPH.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Health professionals responsible for de- veloping national and local protocols and health policies constitute the main target audience of this document.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Obstetricians midwives general medical practitioners  health care managers and public health policy-makers particularly in under-re-WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage 9 sourced settings are also targeted.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The guidance provided is evidence-informed and covers topics related to the management of PPH that were selected and prioritized by an international multidisciplinary group of health care workers consumers and other stakeholders.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: This document establishes general principles of PPH care and it is intended to inform the development of protocols and health policies related to PPH.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: This document is not intended to provide a comprehensive practical guide for the prevention and treatment of PPH.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: MethodsThis guideline is an update of the “WHO recommendations for the prevention of PPH” published in 2007 and the “WHO guidelines for the management of PPH and retained placenta” published in 2009 (6 7).

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: This document represents WHO’s nor- mative support for using evidence-informed policies and practices in all countries.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The guideline forms part of a WHO knowledge-to-action project entitled GREAT (Guideline development Research priorities Evidence synthesis Applicability of evidence Transfer of knowledge) (8) and was developed using standardized operat- ing procedures in accordance with the process described in the “WHO handbook for guideline development” (9).

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: In summary the process included: (i) the identification of critical questions and critical outcomes (ii) the retrieval of the evidence (iii) the assessment and synthesis of evidence (iv) the formulation of recommendations and (v) planning for the dissemination implementation impact evaluation and updating of the guideline.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Two technical groups have worked in the development of this guideline.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: A small operative group composed of staff from the WHO’s Department of Reproductive Health and Research and Department of Maternal Newborn Child and Adolescent Health (MCA) as well as two external experts (see Annex 1 – The guideline steer- ing group) and a larger group with international stakeholders including midwives  obstetricians neonatologists researchers experts in research synthesis experts in health care programmes and consumer representatives (the Guideline Development Group – GDG).

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The guideline steering group was formed in the very beginning of the project and reviewed the previous WHO guidelines on prevention and treatment of PPH (6 7).

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: This group prepared a list of potential additional questions related to the prevention and treatment of PPH.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Next the GDG reviewed and prioritized the draft questions.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The guideline steering group then produced a list of all the questions to be addressed.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: This included both questions from the earlier versions of the guideline as well as new ones.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The guideline steering group also adopted the outcomes used in the 2007 and 2009 guideline documents.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: These outcomes as before were rated on a scale from 1 to 9.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: A question or outcome was defined as ‘critical’ if it was given an average score of 7 or more.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Questions and outcomes with a score of between 4 and 6 were considered ‘important but not critical’ while those with a score lower than 4 were not considered to be important for the purposes of the guideline  (Annex 2).

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage 10 Cochrane systematic reviews of randomized controlled trials (RCTs) were the pri- mary source of evidence for the recommendations2.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Using the assembled list of questions and outcomes the guideline steering group identified Cochrane systematic reviews that were either relevant or potentially relevant and then evaluated wheth- er any needed updating.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: A review was considered to be outdated if the last specified date for new trial searches was two years ago or more or if there were relevant studies still awaiting assessment as identified by the standard search procedures of the Cochrane Pregnancy and Childbirth Group.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Updates were performed using spe- cific standard search strategies.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The corresponding authors of the outdated reviews were invited to update them within a specified time period.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: In instances in which the corresponding authors were unable to do so the updates were undertaken by members of the guideline steering group.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The search strategies employed to identify the trials and the specific criteria for trial inclusion and exclusion are described in the individual systematic reviews.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: A systematic review of literature that included non-randomized trials was carried out by the guideline steering group members when randomized-trial data related to specific questions were scarce.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The following procedures were used to extract the evidence for this guideline from each of these systematic reviews: first the most recent version of the Review Manager (RevMan) file was retrieved from the Cochrane Pregnancy and Childbirth Cochrane Group and customized to reflect the key comparisons and outcomes (those that were not relevant to the guideline were excluded).

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Then the RevMan file was exported to the GRADE profiler software (Grading of Recommendations Assessment  Development and Evaluation) and GRADE criteria were used to critically appraise the retrieved scientific evidence.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Finally evidence profiles (in the form of GRADE tables) were prepared for each comparison.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: An online content management system devel- oped for the GREAT project namely the Guideline Production System was used to handle and share electronic files.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The evidence presented in the GRADE tables was derived from a larger body of data extracted primarily from Cochrane reviews which in many cases contained multiple comparisons (Evidence Base (EB) Tables 1 to 70).

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Each GRADE table relates to one specific question or comparison but some GRADE tables do not contain data for all critical outcomes.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: This is because data for those outcomes were not available in the Cochrane reviews.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The raw data which constitute the basis of the GRADE tables are not included in this document but readers interested in how these GRADE tables were constructed may request access to this information.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The guideline steering group used the information presented in the GRADE tables to check if any existing recommendations (included in the 2007 or 2009 documents) needed to be revised  and to draft recommendations that related to the new questions.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Each recom- mendation was allocated to a thematic module which included the narrative sum- maries of evidence and the relevant GRADE tables.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The standardized criteria used in grading the evidence and the thematic modules (including the GRADE tables) are not included in this document.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: They have been published separately online in a document entitled “WHO recommendations for preventing and treating PPH: evidence base” (www.who.int/reproductivehealth/publications/maternal_perina- tal_health/9789241548502/en).

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: “The Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Inter­ ventions” describes in detail the process of preparing and maintaining Cochrane systematic reviews on the effects of health care interventions.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage 11 A preliminary online consultation was held to review the draft recommendations.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The draft recommendations and supporting evidence were made available to a large number of international stakeholders who were then asked to respond to an online survey.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: In addition the preliminary online consultation identified other previous recommendations that needed to be discussed at the WHO Technical Consultation on the Prevention and Treatment of PPH held in Montreux Switzerland 6–8 March 2012.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: A subset of the international group of experts (who had participated in the online consultations) and other additional experts were invited to attend the Techni- cal Consultation (see Annex 1 for a full list of participants).

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The draft recommen- dations the narrative summaries of evidence the GRADE tables for the new and previous recommendations and other related documents were provided in advance to participants.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Balance worksheets were used during the Technical Consultation to summarize the values preferences and judgements made about the strength of the new and revised recommendations.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Declaration of interest by participants in the WHO Technical Con- sultation According to WHO regulations all experts must declare their relevant interests prior to participation in WHO meetings.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: All GDG members and participants were therefore required to complete a Declaration of Interest Form before the meeting.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: These were reviewed by the guideline steering group before the group composition and invita- tions were finalized.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The external advisers also verbally declared potential conflicts of interest at the beginning of the meeting.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The procedures for the management of conflicts of interests were undertaken in accordance with the “WHO guidelines for declaration of interests (WHO experts)”.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: In summary all members of the GDG declared that they had no commercial or financial interests that were directly or indirectly related to the topic of the meeting/guideline.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Seven members of the GDG were involved in academic work related to the topic of the guideline but this involvement was not considered to be a conflict of interest and the full participation of all the selected experts was deemed appropriate.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: A table summarizing the decla- rations of interest made by members of the GDG is included in Annex 1.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Decision-making during the Technical Consultation At the beginning of the Technical Consultation the participants discussed and ad- opted a list of recommendations which needed to be addressed during the meeting.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: This included the new recommendations as well as previous recommendations that needed to be reviewed and possibly revised.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The following protocol was used for the Technical Consultation: the meeting was structured to allow participants to discuss the proposed list of recommendations and these recommendations were revised as needed through group discussion.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The final adoption of each recommendation was made by consensus – defined as the agree- ment by three quarters or more of the participants – provided that those who dis- agreed did not feel strongly about their position.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Strong disagreements were record- ed as such in the guideline.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: If the participants were unable to reach a consensus  the disputed recommendation or any other decision was put to a vote.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: A recom- mendation or decision stood if a simple majority (more than half of the participants) voted in support of it unless the disagreement related to a safety concern in which case the WHO Secretariat would choose not to issue a recommendation at all.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: WHO staff attending the meeting external technical experts involved in the collectionWHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage 12 and grading of the evidence and observers were not eligible to vote.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: In addition to discussing the scientific evidence and its quality relevant applicability issues costs and other judgements were also taken into consideration when formulating the final recommendations.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The strength of each recommendation was determined during the Technical Con- sultation.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: By default the strength of the recommendations discussed was aligned initially with the quality of the evidence (i.e.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: at the start of the discussion strong recommendations were based on evidence of ‘moderate’ and ‘high’ quality while weak recommendations were based on evidence of ‘low’ and ‘very low’ quality).

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: In addition to the quality of the evidence the following factors were considered when determining the final recommendation and its strength: values and preferenc- es the magnitude of effect the balance of benefits versus disadvantages resource usage and feasibility.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Values and preferences resource usage and the feasibility of each recommendation were based on the experience and opinion of the GDG mem- bers.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Balance worksheets were used to note and synthesize these considerations (Annex 3 Boxes 1 to 8) and record the reasons for changes made to the default strength of the recommendations.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Document preparation and peer review Prior to the Technical Consultation the guideline steering group prepared a prelimi- nary version of this document using a guideline reporting template which had been developed as part of the WHO’s GREAT project.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The draft guideline was reviewed by Technical Consultation participants at the meeting in Montreux.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: During the meeting  the draft guideline was modified in line with participant deliberation and comments.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Feedback received during the preliminary online consultation was also discussed and incorporated into the document where appropriate.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: After the meeting members of the guideline steering group worked to ensure that a revised version of the docu- ment accurately reflected the deliberations and decisions of the participants.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The revised draft guideline document was sent to two external peer reviewers and their inputs were carefully evaluated by the guideline steering group and document revi- sions made accordingly.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The guideline steering group refrained from making substan- tive changes after the meeting in Montreux to the guideline scoping (such as the further expansion of the guideline scoping) or to the recommendations.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The revised version was returned electronically to those who had attended the Technical Consul- tation for their approval.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: ResultsThis guideline includes 32 recommendations for the prevention and treatment of PPH.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Seven of these recommendations are new while the others have been revised in light of new evidence.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Most of the previous 2007 and 2009 recommendations remain unchanged in essence despite updates to the evidence base.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The wording of the previous recommendations has been revised to enhance the clarity of the guidance provided.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The recommendations included in this guideline are based on a total of 22 Cochrane systematic reviews summarized in 70 GRADE tables.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Boxes 1 to 8 present the most up-to-date WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of PPH.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Where applicable remarks related to specific recommendations are also shown in these boxes and new recommendations are marked with asterisks.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Narrative summaries of evidence supporting the recommendations are presentedWHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage 13 in the electronic appendix together with the corresponding GRADE tables (see the “WHO recommendations for preventing and treating PPH: evidence base” at  www.who.int/reproductivehealth/publications/maternal_perinatal_health/ 9789241548502/en).

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Box 9 presents statements related to topics for which accord- ing to the assessments of the GDG there was insufficient evidence to issue a recom- mendation.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Balance worksheets summarizing the values preferences and judge- ments made about the strength of the recommendations are presented in Annex 3  Boxes 1 to 8.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The development of these recommendations involved 130 stakeholders who par- ticipated in the online preliminary survey (representing all WHO regions) and 25 experts who participated in the WHO Technical Consultation.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Recommendations for PPH prevention The contribution of each component of the ‘active management of the third stage of labour’ was examined in light of new available evidence and relevant recommenda- tions were made.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Box 1 presents recommendations concerning the use of uteroton- ics for the prevention of PPH.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: All women giving birth should be offered uteroton- ics during the third stage of labour to prevent PPH and IM/IV oxytocin (10 IU) is recommended as the uterotonic drug of choice.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Other injectable uterotonics (i.e.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: ergometrine/methylergometrine or the fixed drug combination of oxytocin and ergometrine) and misoprostol are recommended as alternatives for the prevention of PPH in settings where oxytocin is unavailable.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Box 2 contains recommendations related to cord management and uterine massage.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The importance of controlled cord traction (CCT) was revisited because of new evidence.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: This intervention is now regarded as optional in settings where skilled birth attendants are available and is contraindicated in settings where skilled attendants do not assist with births.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Early cord clamping is generally contraindicated.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Continuous uterine massage is not recommended as an intervention to prevent PPH for women who have received prophylactic oxytocin because the massage may cause maternal discomfort re- quire a dedicated health professional and may not lead to a reduction of blood loss.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: However surveillance of the uterine tonus through abdominal palpation is recom- mended for all women for the early identification of postpartum uterine atony.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Table 1 summarizes the recommendation status of the individual components of the active management of the third stage of labour.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: In summary the GDG considered the use of uterotonics as the main intervention within the active management of third stage of labour package.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: In this context the use of misoprostol for the prevention of PPH by community health care workers and lay health workers is supported in settings where skilled birth attendants are not present.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Recommendations for reducing blood loss during the third stage of labour in caesar- ean sections are presented in Box 3.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Oxytocin is the recommended uterotonic drug for the prevention of PPH in caesarean sections.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Cord traction is recommended in preference to manual removal when assisting placental delivery in caesarean sec- tions.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Recommendations for PPH treatment The use of uterotonics (oxytocin alone as the first choice) plays a central role in the treatment of PPH (see Boxes 4 and 5).

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Uterine massage is recommended for the treatment of PPH as soon as it is diagnosed (see Box 6) and the initial fluid resus-WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage 14 citation with isotonic crystalloids is recommended.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The use of tranexamic acid is advised in cases of refractory atonic bleeding or persistent trauma-related bleed- ing (see Box 5).

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
