text: The use of intrauterine balloon tamponade is recommended for refractory bleeding or if uterotonics are unavailable.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Bimanual uterine compression  external aortic compression and the use of non-pneumatic anti-shock garments are recommended as temporizing measures until substantive care is available.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: If there is persistent bleeding and the relevant resources are available uterine artery emboli- zation should be considered.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: If bleeding persists despite treatment with uterotonic drugs and other conservative interventions surgical intervention should be used without further delay.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: If the third stage of labour lasts more than 30 minutes CCT and IV/IM oxytocin  (10 IU) should be used to manage the retained placenta.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: If the placenta is retained and bleeding occurs the manual removal of the placenta should be expedited.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Whenever the manual removal of the placenta is undertaken a single dose of pro- phylactic antibiotics is recommended (see Box 7).

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The GDG also issued recommendations related to the organization of PPH care (see Box 8).

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Health facilities delivering maternity services should adopt formal proto- cols for the prevention and treatment of PPH and for patient referral.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The use of PPH treatment simulations for pre-service and in-service training programmes was recommended.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Finally the GDG recommended that the use of uterotonics for the prevention of PPH should be monitored and a specific indicator was suggested.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The GDG found insufficient evidence to recommend one route over another for the prevention of PPH with oxytocin the use of recombinant factor VIIa for the treat- ment of PPH intraumbilical vein injection of oxytocin for treatment of retained placenta and the antenatal distribution of misoprostol.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The GDG also found insuffi- cient evidence to recommend self-administration for the prevention of PPH and the measurement of blood loss over clinical estimation (see Box 9).

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage 15 Box 1: Recommendations for the prevention of PPH – uterotonics 1.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The use of uterotonics for the prevention of PPH during the third stage of labour is recom-mended for all births.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Strong recommendation moderate-quality evidence)2.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Oxytocin (10 IU IV/IM) is the recommended uterotonic drug for the prevention of PPH.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Strong recommendation moderate-quality evidence) 3.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: In settings where oxytocin is unavailable the use of other injectable uterotonics (e.g.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: er-gometrine/methylergometrine or the fixed drug combination of oxytocin and ergometrine) or oral misoprostol (600 µg) is recommended.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Strong recommendation moderate-quality evidence)4.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: In settings where skilled birth attendants are not present and oxytocin is unavailable theadministration of misoprostol (600 µg PO) by community health care workers and lay health workers is recommended for the prevention of PPH.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Strong recommendation moderate- quality evidence)Remarks • Available comparisons are limited but a significant difference between the benefits of oxytocin and ergometrine is unlikely.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: These recommendations place a high value on avoiding the adverse effects of ergometrine and assume a similar benefit from using oxytocin and ergometrine for the prevention of PPH.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: • Caution should be exercised when opting for ergot derivatives for the prevention of PPH as these drugs have clear contraindications in women with hypertensive disorders.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Thus it is probably safer to avoid the use of ergot derivatives in unscreened populations.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: • Misoprostol (600 õg PO) was regarded by the GDG as an effective drug for the prevention of PPH.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: How- õg PO) was regarded by the GDG as an effective drug for the prevention of PPH.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: How- PO) was regarded by the GDG as an effective drug for the prevention of PPH.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: How-ever the GDG considered the relative benefits of oxytocin compared to misoprostol in preventing blood loss as well as the increased adverse effects of misoprostol compared to oxytocin.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The GDG acknowl- edged that there is no evidence to show that a 600 µg dose of misoprostol provides greater efficacy over a 400õg õg dose.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Lower doses have a lower side-effect profi le but the effi cacy of lower doses of miso- õg õg dose.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Lower doses have a lower side-effect profi le but the effi cacy of lower doses of miso- dose.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Lower doses have a lower side-effect profile but the efficacy of lower doses of miso-prostol has not been evaluated sufficiently.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: • The recommendations concerning alternative uterotonics should not detract from the objective of mak- ing oxytocin as widely accessible as possible.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: • In view of past concerns regarding the community-level distribution of misoprostol and the potential for serious consequences of administration before birth the GDG places emphasis on training persons administering misoprostol and monitoring community distribution interventions with scientifically sound methods and appropriate indicators.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage 16 Box 2: Recommendations for the prevention of PPH – cord management and uterine massage 5.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: In settings where skilled birth attendants are available CCT is recommended for vaginalbirths if the care provider and the parturient woman regard a small reduction in blood loss and a small reduction in the duration of the third stage of labour as important.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Weak recom- mendation high-quality evidence)6.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: In settings where skilled birth attendants are unavailable CCT is not recommended.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Strongrecommendation moderate-quality evidence) 7.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Late cord clamping (performed approximately 1 to 3 minutes after birth) is recommendedfor all births while initiating simultaneous essential newborn care.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Strong recommendation  moderate-quality evidence)8.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Early cord clamping (<1 minute after birth) is not recommended unless the neonate is as-phyxiated and needs to be moved immediately for resuscitation.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Strong recommendation  moderate-quality evidence)9.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Sustained uterine massage is not recommended as an intervention to prevent PPH in womenwho have received prophylactic oxytocin.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Weak recommendation low-quality evidence)10.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Postpartum abdominal uterine tonus assessment for early identification of uterine atony isrecommended for all women.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Strong recommendation very-low-quality evidence)Remarks • Recommendations 5 and 6 are based on a large RCT in which oxytocin 10 IU was used for the prevention of PPH in all participants.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Based on this evidence CCT was regarded as safe when applied by skilled birth attendants as it provides small beneficial effects on blood loss (average reduction of 11 ml on blood loss) and on the duration of the third stage of labour (average reduction of 6 minutes).

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The deci- sion to implement CCT in the context of a prophylactic uterotonic drug should be discussed by the care provider and the woman herself.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: • If ergot alkaloids are used for the prevention of PPH then CCT to minimize placenta retention is re- garded as essential.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: • There is insufficient evidence to determine the benefit or risk of CCT when used in conjunction with misoprostol.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: • CCT is the first intervention to treat retained placenta therefore the teaching of CCT in medical and midwifery curricula is essential.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: • The evidence base for recommendations for the timing of cord clamping includes both vaginal and cae- sarean births.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The GDG considers this recommendation to be equally important for caesarean sections.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: • Delayed clamping should be performed during the provision of essential newborn care.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: For essential newborn care and resuscitation please refer to the WHO guidelines on neonatal resuscitation.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (10)• The recommendations for the timing of cord clamping apply equally to preterm and term births.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The GDG considers the benefits of delayed clamping for preterm infants to be particularly important.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Continued on next page) WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage 17 • Some health professionals working in areas of high HIV prevalence have expressed concern regard- ing delayed cord clamping as part of management of the third stage of labour.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: These professionals are concerned that during placental separation a partially detached placenta could be exposed to maternal blood and this could lead to a micro-transfusion of maternal blood to the baby.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: It has been demonstrat- ed that the potential for maternal-to-child transmission of HIV can take place at three different points in time: micro-transfusions of maternal blood to the fetus during pregnancy (intra-uterine HIV transmis- sion) exposure to maternal blood and vaginal secretions when the fetus passes through the birth canal in vaginal deliveries (intra-partum transmission) and during breastfeeding (postnatal infection).

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: For this reason the main intervention to reduce the maternal-to-child transmission is the reduction of mater- nal viral load through the use of antiretroviral drugs during pregnancy childbirth and postnatal period.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: There is no evidence that delaying the cord clamping increases the possibility of HIV transmission from the mother to the newborn.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Maternal blood percolates through the placental intervillous space through- out pregnancy with a relatively low risk of maternal fetal transmission before delivery.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: It is highly un- likely that separation of the placenta increases exposure to maternal blood and is highly unlikely that it disrupts the fetal placental circulation (i.e.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: it is unlikely that during placenta separation the newborn circulation is exposed to maternal blood).

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Thus the proven benefits of a 1 – 3 minute delay at least in clamping the cord outweigh the theoretical and unproven harms.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Late cord clamping is recommended even among women living with HIV or women with unknown HIV status.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: • There is a lack of evidence regarding the role of uterine massage for PPH prevention when no uterotonic drugs are used or if a uterotonic drug other than oxytocin is used.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: • Although the GDG acknowledged that one small study reported that sustained uterine massage and clot expulsion were associated with a reduction in the use of additional uterotonics there is lack of robust evidence supporting other benefits.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: However the GDG considered that routine and frequent uterine tone assessment remains a crucial part of immediate postpartum care particularly for the optimization of early PPH diagnosis.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: • Based on the most recent evidence understanding of the contribution of each component of the active management of the third stage of labour package has evolved.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The GDG considered that this package has a primary intervention: the use of an uterotonic.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: In the context of oxytocin use CCT may add a small benefit while uterine massage may add no benefit for the prevention of PPH.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Early cord clamping is generally contraindicated.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Continued from previous page) WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage 18 Box 3: Recommendations for the prevention of PPH in caesarean sections 11.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Oxytocin (IV or IM) is the recommended uterotonic drug for the prevention of PPH in caesar-ean section.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Strong recommendation moderate-quality evidence)12.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Cord traction is the recommended method for the removal of the placenta in caesarean sec-tion.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Strong recommendation moderate-quality evidence)Remarks • The GDG noted that in terms of blood loss there was not enough evidence to recommend oxytocin infusion over IV bolus injection.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: However due to concerns regarding adverse haemodynamic effects  the GDG considered that if an IV bolus injection is used a slow injection rate is preferred and a rapid injection rate should be avoided.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: • The GDG noted that the combination of an oxytocin infusion after an initial IV bolus of oxytocin after caesarean delivery reduces the need for additional uterotonic agents but does not affect the overall  occurrence of major obstetric haemorrhage.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: • The GDG noted that carbetocin is associated with a reduction in the use of additional uterotonic agents but with no difference in the occurrence of major obstetric haemorrhage.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: In addition the GDG noted that the use of carbetocin is considerably more expensive than oxytocin.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: This remark is equally appli- cable to vaginal deliveries.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Table 1: Recommendation status of the individual components of the active management  of the third stage of labour based on who delivers the intervention Skilled  birth attendant Non-skilled  birth attendant Self-administered Uterotonics In favour In favour Research* Early cord clamping Against Against Against Controlled cord traction Conditional** Against Against Continuous uterine massage Against*** Against Research**** * Distribution of misoprostol during the antenatal period for self-administration during the third stage of labour ** Small reduction in blood loss and in the length of the third stage adoption based on the values and preferences of the woman and the health care provider *** Routine uterine tone assessment remains a vital part of clinical decision making and should be practised during the third stage of labour **** Self-administered uterine massage in the absence of uterotonics WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage 19 Box 4: Recommendations for the treatment of PPH – uterotonics 13.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Intravenous oxytocin is the recommended uterotonic drug for the treatment of PPH.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Strongrecommendation moderate quality evidence) 14.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: If intravenous oxytocin is unavailable or if the bleeding does not respond to oxytocin the useof intravenous ergometrine oxytocin-ergometrine fixed dose or a prostaglandin drug (includ- ing sublingual misoprostol 800 µg) is recommended.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Strong recommendation low-quality evidence)Remarks • The GDG recommended IV oxytocin as the first line uterotonic drug for the treatment of PPH including when women have already received this drug for the prophylaxis of PPH.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: • The GDG recognized that IV oxytocin may not be available in all settings.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: It encourages health care decision-makers in these settings to strive to make oxytocin available.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: • In settings where IV oxytocin is unavailable to women who have received prophylactic IM oxytocin during the third stage of labour the GDG considered misoprostol to be a valid alternative.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: • If PPH prophylaxis with misoprostol has been administered and if injectable uterotonics are unavailable  there is insufficient evidence to guide further misoprostol dosing and consideration must be given to the risk of potential toxicity.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: • There is no added benefit to offering misoprostol simultaneously to women receiving oxytocin for the treatment of PPH (i.e.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: adjunct misoprostol).

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: • The GDG noted that the two largest trials of misoprostol for the treatment of PPH (Winikoff 2010 Blum 2010) reported the use of a 800 μg dose administered sublingually.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The majority of the GDG members agreed that 800 μg is an acceptable sublingual misoprostol dose for the treatment of PPH though some members of the GDG expressed concern related to the risk of hyperpyrexia associated with this dosage.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: • If IV oxytocin has been used for the treatment of PPH and the bleeding does not stop there is a paucity of data to recommend preferences for second line uterotonic drug treatment.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Decisions in such situ- ations must be guided by the experience of the provider the availability of the drugs and by known contraindications.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: • In situations in which IM oxytocin can be administered and there is no possibility of IV treatment with ergot alkaloids/injectable prostaglandins there is a paucity of data to recommend a preference of IM oxytocin over misoprostol or other uterotonics.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Decisions in such situations must be guided by the expe- rience of the provider the availability of the drugs and by known contraindications.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Box 5: Recommendations for the treatment of PPH – fluid resuscitation and tranexamic acid 15.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The use of isotonic crystalloids is recommended in preference to the use of colloids for theintravenous fluid resuscitation of women with PPH.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Strong recommendation low-quality evidence)16.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The use of tranexamic acid is recommended for the treatment of PPH if oxytocin and otheruterotonics fail to stop the bleeding or if it is thought that the bleeding may be partly due to trauma.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Weak recommendation moderate-quality evidence)Remarks • Evidence for the recommendation of tranexamic acid was extrapolated from the literature on surgery and trauma which shows tranexamic acid to be a safe option for the treatment of trauma-related bleeding.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage 20 Box 6: Recommendations for the treatment of PPH – manoeuvres and other procedures 17.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Uterine massage is recommended for the treatment of PPH.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Strong recommendation very-low-quality evidence) 18.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: If women do not respond to treatment using uterotonics or if uterotonics are unavailablethe use of intrauterine balloon tamponade is recommended for the treatment of PPH due to uterine atony.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Weak recommendation very-low-quality evidence)19.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: If other measures have failed and if the necessary resources are available the use of uter-ine artery embolization is recommended as a treatment for PPH due to uterine atony.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Weak recommendation very-low-quality evidence)20.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: If bleeding does not stop in spite of treatment using uterotonics and other available conserva-tive interventions (e.g.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: uterine massage balloon tamponade) the use of surgical interven- tions is recommended.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Strong recommendation very-low-quality evidence)21.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The use of bimanual uterine compression is recommended as a temporizing measure untilappropriate care is available for the treatment of PPH due to uterine atony after vaginal delivery.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Weak recommendation very-low-quality evidence)22.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The use of external aortic compression for the treatment of PPH due to uterine atony aftervaginal birth is recommended as a temporizing measure until appropriate care is available.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Weak recommendation very-low-quality evidence)23.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The use of non-pneumatic anti-shock garments is recommended as a temporizing measureuntil appropriate care is available.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Weak recommendation low-quality evidence)24.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The use of uterine packing is not recommended for the treatment of PPH due to uterineatony after vaginal birth.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Weak recommendation very-low-quality evidence)Remarks • The GDG noted that the application of these interventions requires training and that maternal discom- fort and complications associated with these procedures have been reported.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: • Uterine massage as a therapeutic measure is defined as the rubbing of the uterus achieved through the manual massaging of the abdomen.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: This is typically sustained until the bleeding stops or the uterus con- tracts.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The GDP considered that uterine massage should be started once PPH has been diagnosed.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: • The initial rubbing of the uterus and expression of blood clots are not regarded as therapeutic uterine massage.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: • When rating the recommendation #17 as ‘strong’ the low cost and safety of uterine massage were taken into account.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: • The use of balloon tamponade was considered by the GDG to be a measure that can potentially avoid surgery or as a temporizing measure while awaiting transfer to a higher level facility.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The GDG acknowl- edges that balloon tamponade can be obtained with specific devices as well as with lower cost adapta- tions including those based on the use of condoms and surgical gloves.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: • The GDG noted that uterine artery embolization requires significant resources in terms of the cost of the treatment the facilities and the training of health care workers.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: • The GDG noted that conservative surgical approaches should be tried first.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: If these do not work they should be followed by more invasive procedures.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Compression sutures for example may be attempted as a first intervention and if these fail then uterine utero-ovarian and hypogastric vessel ligation may be tried.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: If life-threatening bleeding continues even after ligation then a subtotal (otherwise known as supracervical) or total hysterectomy should be performed.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: • The GDG acknowledged that the level of health care provider skills will play a role in the selection and sequence of the surgical interventions.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Continued on next page) WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage 21 • External aortic compression has long been recommended as a potential life-saving technique and me- chanical compression of the aorta if successful slows blood loss.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The GDG placed a high value on this procedure as a temporizing measure in the treatment of PPH.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: • The GDG noted that research evaluating the potential benefits and harms of non-pneumatic anti-shock garments is ongoing.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Based on the evidence available the GDG regarded non-pneumatic anti-shock gar- ments as a temporizing measure while transfer is awaited.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: • The GDG noted that there was no evidence of benefit of uterine packing and placed a high value on concerns regarding its potential harm.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Box 7: Recommendations for the treatment of retained placenta 25.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: If the placenta is not expelled spontaneously the use of additional oxytocin (10 IU IV/IM) incombination with controlled cord traction is recommended.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Weak recommendation very- low-quality evidence)26.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The use of ergometrine for the management of a retained placenta is not recommended asthis may cause tetanic uterine contractions which may delay the expulsion of the placenta.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Weak recommendation very-low-quality evidence)27.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The use of prostaglandin E2 alpha (dinoprostone or sulprostone) in the management of re-tained placenta is not recommended.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Weak recommendation very-low-quality evidence)28.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: A single dose of antibiotics (ampicillin or first-generation cephalosporin) is recommended ifmanual removal of the placenta is practised.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Weak recommendation very-low-quality evi- dence)Remarks • The GDG found no empirical evidence to support recommending the use of uterotonics for the manage- ment of a retained placenta in the absence of haemorrhage.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The above recommendation was reached by consensus.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: • The WHO guide “Managing complications in pregnancy and childbirth” (WHO 2007) states that if a placenta is not expelled within 30 minutes after the delivery of a baby the woman should be diagnosed as having a retained placenta.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Since there is no evidence for or against this definition the delay used before this condition is diagnosed is left to the judgement of the clinician.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: • The same WHO guide also suggests that in the absence of haemorrhage the woman should be observed for a further 30 minutes after the initial 30 minutes before the manual removal of the placenta is at- tempted.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The GDG noted that spontaneous expulsion of the placenta can still occur even in the absence of bleeding.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: A conservative approach is therefore advised and the timing of the manual removal of the placenta as a definitive treatment is left to the judgement of the clinician.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: • The recommendation regarding the use of prostaglandin E2 is informed by a lack of evidence on this question and also by concerns related to adverse events particularly cardiac events.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: • Direct evidence of the value of antibiotic prophylaxis after the manual removal of the placenta was not available.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The GDG considered indirect evidence of the benefit of prophylactic antibiotics from studies of caesarean section and abortion as well as observational studies of other intrauterine manipulations.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: • Current practice suggests that ampicillin or first-generation cephalosporins may be administered when the manual removal of the placenta is performed.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: • This question was identified as a research priority for settings in which prophylactic antibiotics are not routinely administered and those with low infectious morbidity.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Continued from previous page) WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage 22 Box 8: Health Systems and Organization of Care recommendations for the prevention and treatment of PPH 29.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The use of formal protocols by health facilities for the prevention and treatment of PPH isrecommended.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Weak recommendation moderate-quality evidence)30.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The use of formal protocols for referral of women to a higher level of care is recommendedfor health facilities.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Weak recommendation very-low-quality evidence)31.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The use of simulations of PPH treatment is recommended for pre-service and in-service train-ing programmes.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Weak recommendation very-low-quality evidence)32.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Monitoring the use of uterotonics after birth for the prevention of PPH is recommended asa process indicator for programmatic evaluation.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (Weak recommendation very-low-quality evidence)Remarks • Routine and frequent uterine tone assessment remains a crucial part of immediate postpartum care  particularly for optimizing the early diagnosis of PPH.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: • The GDG acknowledged that the implementation of formal protocols is a complex process which will require the local adaptation of general guidelines.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: • The GDG placed a high value on the costs of simulation programmes and acknowledged that there are different types of simulation programmes.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Some programmes are hi-tech computerized and costly while others are less expensive and more likely to be affordable in low- and middle-income countries.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The GDG identified improvement in communication between health care providers and patients and their family members as an important priority in the training of health care providers in PPH management.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: • The GDG recommended monitoring the use of prophylactic uterotonics.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: This recommendation is based on experience from other areas of health care particularly child health where content-based health indicators are common and regarded as useful for programmatic purposes.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The suggested indicator is calculated as the number of women receiving prophylactic uterotonic drugs after birth divided by all women giving birth.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage 23 Box 9: Statements related to topics for which there is insufficient evidence to issue a recom- mendation A.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: There is insufficient evidence to recommend one oxytocin route over another for the prevention of PPH.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: B.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: There is insufficient evidence to recommend the use of recombinant factor VIIa for the treatment ofPPH.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: C.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: There is insufficient evidence to recommend the use of intraumbilical vein injection of oxytocin as atreatment for retained placenta.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: D.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: There is insufficient evidence to recommend the antenatal distribution of misoprostol to pregnantwomen for self-administration for the prevention of PPH.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: E.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: There is insufficient evidence to recommend the measurement of blood loss over clinical estimation ofblood loss.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Remarks • The GDG noted that there are three ongoing trials in which the IV and IM routes for oxytocin administra- tion are being compared for the prevention of PPH.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: • The GDG considered there to be insufficient evidence to recommend the use of oxytocin infusion over IV bolus injection with regard to blood loss.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: However in light of concerns about the potential adverse haemodynamic effects the GDG considered that if IV bolus injection treatment is to be used then a slow injection rate is preferred and a rapid injection rate should be avoided.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: • In the context of PPH the GDP considered that the use of recombinant factor VIIa should be limited to women with specific haematological indications.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The group regarded the recombinant factor VIIa as a potentially life-saving drug but noted that it is also associated with life-threatening side-effects.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: More- over recombinant factor VIIa is expensive and may be difficult to administer.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: • The GDG acknowledged that while there is a paucity of data to recommend intraumbilical vein injec- tion of oxytocin as a treatment for retained placenta the procedure itself has not been shown to cause harm and demonstrates a non-significant trend towards a lower risk of requiring the manual removal of the placenta.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: • The GDG acknowledged that a number of countries have embarked on community-level programmes of misoprostol distribution and considered that this should be done in the context of research (where reli- able data on coverage safety and health outcomes can be collected).

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: • The GDG noted that all trials included in the systematic review on the measurement of blood loss were conducted in developed countries and views the applicability of this evidence to low- and middle- income countries as very uncertain.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage 24 4.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Research implicationsThe GDG identified important knowledge gaps that need to be addressed through primary research.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: In this guideline recommendations based on evidence quality that was rated as ‘very low’ or ‘low’ require further research.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Conversely further re- search is not a priority for those recommendations based on evidence of ‘moderate’ or ‘high’ quality.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Knowledge gaps identified in the 2007 and 2009 WHO documents were also reviewed.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The identified knowledge gaps were prioritized by considering whether such research would be feasible innovative original likely to promote equity and contribute to the reduction of the burden of PPH.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The main barriers to scaling up the intervention were also considered in this prioritization exercise.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The GDG noted that research is either planned or ongoing for some of the research priorities identified.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: However there is no certainty that these investigations will provide conclusive results and the topics have therefore remained listed as re- search priorities in this document.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Key research priority In settings where the use of injectable uterotonics is not feasible what are the ef- fects of antenatal distribution of misoprostol to pregnant women for self-administra- tion during the third stage of labour? Other research questions • What is the minimum effective dose of oxytocin for the prevention of PPH? • What are the effects of IM oxytocin (versus IV oxytocin) for the prevention of PPH? • Can oxytocin be administered safely by unskilled attendants? • What are the effects of buccal and sublingual use of oxytocin for the prevention of PPH? • What is the minimum effective dose of misoprostol for the prevention of PPH? • What is the minimum effective dose of misoprostol for the treatment of PPH? • What are effects and safety of misoprostol as treatment for PPH in women who received misoprostol as PPH prophylaxis? • Should misoprostol be used in addition to oxytocin for PPH prevention? • What are the effects of tranexamic acid in PPH treatment? • What are the effects of uterine massage for the prevention of PPH? • What are the effects of uterine massage to prevent PPH where oxytocin is not available? • What are the effects of uterine balloon or tamponade in the treatment of PPH? • What are the effects of uterine massage to prevent PPH where only misoprostol is available? WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage 25 • What are the effects of prophylactic antibiotics after manual extraction of the placenta as part of the treatment of retained placenta? • What are the effects of the use of misoprostol for the treatment of retained placenta? • What are effects of ergometrine (in combination or not with oxytocin) after caesarean section for the prevention of PPH? • What is the optimal time for cord clamping in the context of physiologic and ac- tive management of third stage of labour? • What is the appropriate time to administer oxytocin for PPH prevention rela- tive to cord clamping and placental delivery?

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: (i.e.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: before/after cord clamping  before/after placenta delivery)• Which clinical consequences of blood loss are of greatest value for the diagnosis and treatment of PPH? • What is the role of lay health workers in management of PPH? 5.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Dissemination and implementation of the guidelineThe ultimate goal of this guideline is to improve the quality of care and health outcomes related to PPH.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Therefore the dissemination and implementation of this guideline are crucial steps that should be undertaken by the international commu- nity and local health care services.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The WHO Department of Reproductive Health and Research has adopted a formal knowledge-to-action framework for the dissemi- nation adaptation and implementation of guidelines (8).

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: In addition to this frame- work a list of priority actions was established during the WHO Technical Consulta- tion which will be used by the WHO and other partners to foster the dissemination and implementation of this guideline (EB Box 2).

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Guideline dissemination and evaluation The recommendations in this guideline will be disseminated through a broad net- work of international partners including WHO country and regional offices min- istries of health WHO collaborating centres other United Nations agencies and non-governmental organizations.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: A policy brief will also be developed for a wide range of policy-makers programme managers and clinicians and then disseminated through WHO country offices.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Guideline implementation The successful introduction of evidence-based policies related to the prevention and management of PPH into national programmes and health care services depends on well-planned and participatory consensus-driven processes of adaptation and imple- WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage 26 mentation.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: These processes may include the development or revision of existing national guidelines or protocols based on this document.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The recommendations contained in the present guideline should be adapted into locally-appropriate documents that are able to meet the specific needs of each country and health service.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Modifications to the recommendations where necessary  should be limited to weak recommendations and justifications for any changes made in an explicit and transparent manner.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: An enabling environment should be created for the use of these recommendations (for example by widening the availability of uterotonics) including changes in the behaviour of health care practitioners to enable the use of evidence-based practic- es.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Local professional societies may play important roles in this process and an all- inclusive and participatory process should be encouraged.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The WHO’s Department of Reproductive Health and Research has published specific guidance on the introduc- tion of the WHO’s reproductive health guidelines and tools in national programmes.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Applicability issuesAnticipated impact on the organization of care and  resources The evidence-based prevention and management of PPH can be achieved with the use of relatively inexpensive drugs.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: However the GDG noted that the following is- sues should be considered before the recommendations made in this current guide- line are applied:• Women should not be left alone during the first hours after delivery of the baby and the placenta • In settings where oxytocin is used attention should be paid to the oxytocin cold chain (i.e.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: the requirements of a temperature-controlled supply chain)• Health services adopting late cord clamping should also adopt strategies to iden- tify (and if necessary to treat) neonatal jaundice Monitoring and evaluating the guideline implementation The implementation of the recommendations in this guideline should be monitored at the health-service level.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Interrupted time series clinical audits or criterion-based clinical audits could be used to obtain relevant data related to the management of PPH.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Clearly-defined review criteria and indicators are needed and these could be associated with locally-agreed targets.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The GDG strongly recommends that the cov- erage of prophylactic uterotonics be used as a process indicator for the monitoring and prevention of PPH.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: • Prophylactic Uterotonic Coverage Indicator: The suggested indicator is calculat- ed as the number of women receiving prophylactic uterotonics during the third stage of labour divided by all women giving birth This indicator provides an overall assessment of adherence to a key recommendation included in this guideline.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The use of other locally-agreed and more specific indica-WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage 27 tors (e.g.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: the assessment of the use of specific uterotonics) may be necessary to obtain a more complete assessment of the quality of care related to the prevention and treatment of PPH.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: WHO has developed specific guidance for evaluating the qual- ity of care for severe maternal complications (including PPH) based on the near-miss and criterion-based clinical audit concepts (13).

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Updating the guidelineThis guideline will be updated in 2017 or following the identification of new evi- dence that indicates a need to revise these recommendations.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: WHO welcomes sug- gestions regarding additional questions for inclusion in the updated guideline.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Please e-mail your suggestions to: reproductivehealth@who.int.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Template for the summary of considerations related to the strength of the recommendations with explanations for completing the templateRecommendation Which recommendation? Intervention What is the intervention? Quality of the evidence  High  Moderate  Low  Very low The higher the quality of the evidence the stronger the recommendation.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: If the evidence quality is ‘low’ or ‘very low’ consider more carefully the other criteria below in deciding the strength of the recommendation.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Values and preferences  No significant variability  Significant variability This refers to values placed by health workers policy-makers patients and other stakeholders on the intended outcomes of the interventions.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: If there is wide variability between the values and preferences of various stakeholders the intervention is less likely to have a strong recommendation.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Magnitude of effect in critical outcomes  Large effect (RR>2 or RR<0.5)  Small effect (0.5<RR<2) This refers to the potential of the intervention to have large effects.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The effects can be enhanced by being combined withother interventions.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Consider which potential associations (or ‘bundles’) can enhance effects.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The larger the potential effects and the longer the time period of the potential effects the more likely the intervention is to have a strong recommendation.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Balance of benefits versus disadvantages  Benefits outweigh disadvantages  Benefits and disadvantages are balanced  Disadvantages outweigh benefits Benefits refer to the intended positive effects of an intervention .

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Disadvantages refer to the potentially negative effects of an intervention as well as its unintended effects.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The fewer the potentially negative effects there are the more likely the intervention is to receive a strong recommendation.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Resource use  Less resource intensive  More resource intensive The resources needed for the implementation of a recommendation may include financial resources human resources  and infrastructure or equipment.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Ideally the cost of the benefits of an intervention should be reasonable affordable andsustainable.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: It should be remembered that capital costs such as those required for infrastructural development may beinitially high but may also yield long-term benefits.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Generally interventions that incur higher incremental or recurrent costs are less likely to be strongly recommended.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Feasibility  Yes globally  Yes conditionally Political commitment and wide stakeholder engagement are prerequisites for interventions.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The ‘technical’ feasibility ofinterventions also depends on sufficiently functional organizational and institutional structures to manage follow through  and monitor the implementation of the recommendation.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: The elements of technical feasibility vary considerably by countryand by context where these elements are likely to be functional across a wide variety of settings it is more likely that interventions will receive strong recommendations.

fname: WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
text: Recommendation direction  In favour of the intervention  Against the intervention Overall ranking  Strong recommendation  Weak recommendation Strength of the recommendation.
